title: Making sense of string theory
transcript: In the year 1919, a virtually unknown German mathematician, named Theodor Kaluza suggested a very bold and, in some ways, a very bizarre idea. He proposed that our universe might actually have more than the three dimensions that we are all aware of. That is in addition to left, right, back, forth and up, down, Kaluza proposed that there might be additional dimensions of space that for some reason we don't yet see. Now, when someone makes a bold and bizarre idea, sometimes that's all it is — bold and bizarre, but it has nothing to do with the world around us. This particular idea, however — although we don't yet know whether it's right or wrong, and at the end I'll discuss experiments which, in the next few years, may tell us whether it's right or wrong — this idea has had a major impact on physics in the last century and continues to inform a lot of cutting-edge research.So, I'd like to tell you something about the story of these extra dimensions. So where do we go? To begin we need a little bit of back story. Go to 1907. This is a year when Einstein is basking in the glow of having discovered the special theory of relativity and decides to take on a new project, to try to understand fully the grand, pervasive force of gravity. And in that moment, there are many people around who thought that that project had already been resolved. Newton had given the world a theory of gravity in the late 1600s that works well, describes the motion of planets, the motion of the moon and so forth, the motion of apocryphal of apples falling from trees, hitting people on the head. All of that could be described using Newton's work.But Einstein realized that Newton had left something out of the story, because even Newton had written that although he understood how to calculate the effect of gravity, he'd been unable to figure out how it really works. How is it that the Sun, 93 million miles away, [that] somehow it affects the motion of the Earth? How does the Sun reach out across empty inert space and exert influence? And that is a task to which Einstein set himself — to figure out how gravity works. And let me show you what it is that he found. So Einstein found that the medium that transmits gravity is space itself. The idea goes like this: imagine space is a substrate of all there is.Einstein said space is nice and flat, if there's no matter present. But if there is matter in the environment, such as the Sun, it causes the fabric of space to warp, to curve. And that communicates the force of gravity. Even the Earth warps space around it. Now look at the Moon. The Moon is kept in orbit, according to these ideas, because it rolls along a valley in the curved environment that the Sun and the Moon and the Earth can all create by virtue of their presence. We go to a full-frame view of this. The Earth itself is kept in orbit because it rolls along a valley in the environment that's curved because of the Sun's presence. That is this new idea about how gravity actually works.Now, this idea was tested in 1919 through astronomical observations. It really works. It describes the data. And this gained Einstein prominence around the world. And that is what got Kaluza thinking. He, like Einstein, was in search of what we call a unified theory. That's one theory that might be able to describe all of nature's forces from one set of ideas, one set of principles, one master equation, if you will. So Kaluza said to himself, Einstein has been able to describe gravity in terms of warps and curves in space — in fact, space and time, to be more precise. Maybe I can play the same game with the other known force, which was, at that time, known as the electromagnetic force — we know of others today, but at that time that was the only other one people were thinking about. You know, the force responsible for electricity and magnetic attraction and so forth.So Kaluza says, maybe I can play the same game and describe electromagnetic force in terms of warps and curves. That raised a question: warps and curves in what? Einstein had already used up space and time, warps and curves, to describe gravity. There didn't seem to be anything else to warp or curve. So Kaluza said, well, maybe there are more dimensions of space. He said, if I want to describe one more force, maybe I need one more dimension. So he imagined that the world had four dimensions of space, not three, and imagined that electromagnetism was warps and curves in that fourth dimension. Now here's the thing: when he wrote down the equations describing warps and curves in a universe with four space dimensions, not three, he found the old equations that Einstein had already derived in three dimensions — those were for gravity — but he found one more equation because of the one more dimension. And when he looked at that equation, it was none other than the equation that scientists had long known to describe the electromagnetic force. Amazing — it just popped out. He was so excited by this realization that he ran around his house screaming, "Victory!" — that he had found the unified theory.Now clearly, Kaluza was a man who took theory very seriously. He, in fact — there is a story that when he wanted to learn how to swim, he read a book, a treatise on swimming — (Laughter) — then dove into the ocean. This is a man who would risk his life on theory. Now, but for those of us who are a little bit more practically minded, two questions immediately arise from his observation. Number one: if there are more dimensions in space, where are they? We don't seem to see them. And number two: does this theory really work in detail, when you try to apply it to the world around us? Now, the first question was answered in 1926 by a fellow named Oskar Klein. He suggested that dimensions might come in two varieties — there might be big, easy-to-see dimensions, but there might also be tiny, curled-up dimensions, curled up so small, even though they're all around us, that we don't see them.Let me show you that one visually. So, imagine you're looking at something like a cable supporting a traffic light. It's in Manhattan. You're in Central Park — it's kind of irrelevant — but the cable looks one-dimensional from a distant viewpoint, but you and I all know that it does have some thickness. It's very hard to see it, though, from far away. But if we zoom in and take the perspective of, say, a little ant walking around — little ants are so small that they can access all of the dimensions — the long dimension, but also this clockwise, counter-clockwise direction. And I hope you appreciate this. It took so long to get these ants to do this.(Laughter)But this illustrates the fact that dimensions can be of two sorts: big and small. And the idea that maybe the big dimensions around us are the ones that we can easily see, but there might be additional dimensions curled up, sort of like the circular part of that cable, so small that they have so far remained invisible. Let me show you what that would look like. So, if we take a look, say, at space itself — I can only show, of course, two dimensions on a screen. Some of you guys will fix that one day, but anything that's not flat on a screen is a new dimension, goes smaller, smaller, smaller, and way down in the microscopic depths of space itself, this is the idea, you could have additional curled up dimensions —here is a little shape of a circle — so small that we don't see them. But if you were a little ultra microscopic ant walking around, you could walk in the big dimensions that we all know about — that's like the grid part — but you could also access the tiny curled-up dimension that's so small that we can't see it with the naked eye or even with any of our most refined equipment. But deeply tucked into the fabric of space itself, the idea is there could be more dimensions, as we see there. Now that's an explanation about how the universe could have more dimensions than the ones that we see. But what about the second question that I asked: does the theory actually work when you try to apply it to the real world?Well, it turns out that Einstein and Kaluza and many others worked on trying to refine this framework and apply it to the physics of the universe as was understood at the time, and, in detail, it didn't work. In detail, for instance, they couldn't get the mass of the electron to work out correctly in this theory. So many people worked on it, but by the '40s, certainly by the '50s, this strange but very compelling idea of how to unify the laws of physics had gone away. Until something wonderful happened in our age. In our era, a new approach to unify the laws of physics is being pursued by physicists such as myself, many others around the world, it's called superstring theory, as you were indicating. And the wonderful thing is that superstring theory has nothing to do at first sight with this idea of extra dimensions, but when we study superstring theory, we find that it resurrects the idea in a sparkling, new form.So, let me just tell you how that goes. Superstring theory — what is it? Well, it's a theory that tries to answer the question: what are the basic, fundamental, indivisible, uncuttable constituents making up everything in the world around us? The idea is like this. So, imagine we look at a familiar object, just a candle in a holder, and imagine that we want to figure out what it is made of. So we go on a journey deep inside the object and examine the constituents. So deep inside — we all know, you go sufficiently far down, you have atoms. We also all know that atoms are not the end of the story. They have little electrons that swarm around a central nucleus with neutrons and protons. Even the neutrons and protons have smaller particles inside of them known as quarks. That is where conventional ideas stop.Here is the new idea of string theory. Deep inside any of these particles, there is something else. This something else is this dancing filament of energy. It looks like a vibrating string — that's where the idea, string theory comes from. And just like the vibrating strings that you just saw in a cello can vibrate in different patterns, these can also vibrate in different patterns. They don't produce different musical notes. Rather, they produce the different particles making up the world around us. So if these ideas are correct, this is what the ultra-microscopic landscape of the universe looks like. It's built up of a huge number of these little tiny filaments of vibrating energy, vibrating in different frequencies. The different frequencies produce the different particles. The different particles are responsible for all the richness in the world around us.And there you see unification, because matter particles, electrons and quarks, radiation particles, photons, gravitons, are all built up from one entity. So matter and the forces of nature all are put together under the rubric of vibrating strings. And that's what we mean by a unified theory. Now here is the catch. When you study the mathematics of string theory, you find that it doesn't work in a universe that just has three dimensions of space. It doesn't work in a universe with four dimensions of space, nor five, nor six. Finally, you can study the equations, and show that it works only in a universe that has 10 dimensions of space and one dimension of time. It leads us right back to this idea of Kaluza and Klein — that our world, when appropriately described, has more dimensions than the ones that we see.Now you might think about that and say, well, OK, you know, if you have extra dimensions, and they're really tightly curled up, yeah, perhaps we won't see them, if they're small enough. But if there's a little tiny civilization of green people walking around down there, and you make them small enough, and we won't see them either. That is true. One of the other predictions of string theory — no, that's not one of the other predictions of string theory.(Laughter)But it raises the question: are we just trying to hide away these extra dimensions, or do they tell us something about the world? In the remaining time, I'd like to tell you two features of them. First is, many of us believe that these extra dimensions hold the answer to what perhaps is the deepest question in theoretical physics, theoretical science. And that question is this: when we look around the world, as scientists have done for the last hundred years, there appear to be about 20 numbers that really describe our universe. These are numbers like the mass of the particles, like electrons and quarks, the strength of gravity, the strength of the electromagnetic force — a list of about 20 numbers that have been measured with incredible precision, but nobody has an explanation for why the numbers have the particular values that they do.Now, does string theory offer an answer? Not yet. But we believe the answer for why those numbers have the values they do may rely on the form of the extra dimensions. And the wonderful thing is, if those numbers had any other values than the known ones, the universe, as we know it, wouldn't exist. This is a deep question. Why are those numbers so finely tuned to allow stars to shine and planets to form, when we recognize that if you fiddle with those numbers — if I had 20 dials up here and I let you come up and fiddle with those numbers, almost any fiddling makes the universe disappear. So can we explain those 20 numbers? And string theory suggests that those 20 numbers have to do with the extra dimensions. Let me show you how. So when we talk about the extra dimensions in string theory, it's not one extra dimension, as in the older ideas of Kaluza and Klein. This is what string theory says about the extra dimensions. They have a very rich, intertwined geometry.This is an example of something known as a Calabi-Yau shape — name isn't all that important. But, as you can see, the extra dimensions fold in on themselves and intertwine in a very interesting shape, interesting structure. And the idea is that if this is what the extra dimensions look like, then the microscopic landscape of our universe all around us would look like this on the tiniest of scales. When you swing your hand, you'd be moving around these extra dimensions over and over again, but they're so small that we wouldn't know it. So what is the physical implication, though, relevant to those 20 numbers?Consider this. If you look at the instrument, a French horn, notice that the vibrations of the airstreams are affected by the shape of the instrument. Now in string theory, all the numbers are reflections of the way strings can vibrate. So just as those airstreams are affected by the twists and turns in the instrument, strings themselves will be affected by the vibrational patterns in the geometry within which they are moving. So let me bring some strings into the story. And if you watch these little fellows vibrating around — they'll be there in a second — right there, notice that they way they vibrate is affected by the geometry of the extra dimensions.So, if we knew exactly what the extra dimensions look like — we don't yet, but if we did — we should be able to calculate the allowed notes, the allowed vibrational patterns. And if we could calculate the allowed vibrational patterns, we should be able to calculate those 20 numbers. And if the answer that we get from our calculations agrees with the values of those numbers that have been determined through detailed and precise experimentation, this in many ways would be the first fundamental explanation for why the structure of the universe is the way it is. Now, the second issue that I want to finish up with is: how might we test for these extra dimensions more directly? Is this just an interesting mathematical structure that might be able to explain some previously unexplained features of the world, or can we actually test for these extra dimensions? And we think — and this is, I think, very exciting — that in the next five years or so we may be able to test for the existence of these extra dimensions.Here's how it goes. In CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, a machine is being built called the Large Hadron Collider. It's a machine that will send particles around a tunnel, opposite directions, near the speed of light. Every so often those particles will be aimed at each other, so there's a head-on collision. The hope is that if the collision has enough energy, it may eject some of the debris from the collision from our dimensions, forcing it to enter into the other dimensions. How would we know it? Well, we'll measure the amount of energy after the collision, compare it to the amount of energy before, and if there's less energy after the collision than before, this will be evidence that the energy has drifted away. And if it drifts away in the right pattern that we can calculate, this will be evidence that the extra dimensions are there.Let me show you that idea visually. So, imagine we have a certain kind of particle called a graviton — that's the kind of debris we expect to be ejected out, if the extra dimensions are real. But here's how the experiment will go. You take these particles. You slam them together. You slam them together, and if we are right, some of the energy of that collision will go into debris that flies off into these extra dimensions. So this is the kind of experiment that we'll be looking at in the next five, seven to 10 years or so. And if this experiment bears fruit, if we see that kind of particle ejected by noticing that there's less energy in our dimensions than when we began, this will show that the extra dimensions are real.And to me this is a really remarkable story, and a remarkable opportunity. Going back to Newton with absolute space — didn't provide anything but an arena, a stage in which the events of the universe take place. Einstein comes along and says, well, space and time can warp and curve — that's what gravity is. And now string theory comes along and says, yes, gravity, quantum mechanics, electromagnetism, all together in one package, but only if the universe has more dimensions than the ones that we see. And this is an experiment that may test for them in our lifetime. Amazing possibility. Thank you very much.(Applause)

the long dimension,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
but also this clockwise, counter-clockwise direction.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
And I hope you appreciate this.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
It took so long to get these ants to do this.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:15.958
(Laughter)

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
But this illustrates the fact that dimensions can be of two sorts:

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:22.958
big and small. And the idea that maybe the big dimensions around us

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
are the ones that we can easily see,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
but there might be additional dimensions curled up,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
sort of like the circular part of that cable,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:33.958
so small that they have so far remained invisible.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Let me show you what that would look like.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
So, if we take a look, say, at space itself --

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:42.958
I can only show, of course, two dimensions on a screen.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
Some of you guys will fix that one day,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
but anything that's not flat on a screen is a new dimension,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
goes smaller, smaller, smaller,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:52.958
and way down in the microscopic depths of space itself,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:53.958
this is the idea,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
you could have additional curled up dimensions --

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
here is a little shape of a circle -- so small that we don't see them.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
But if you were a little ultra microscopic ant walking around,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
you could walk in the big dimensions that we all know about --

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
that's like the grid part --

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
but you could also access the tiny curled-up dimension

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
that's so small that we can't see it with the naked eye

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
or even with any of our most refined equipment.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
But deeply tucked into the fabric of space itself,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:21.958
the idea is there could be more dimensions, as we see there.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:25.958
Now that's an explanation

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
about how the universe could have more dimensions than the ones that we see.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
But what about the second question that I asked:

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
does the theory actually work

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
when you try to apply it to the real world?

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
Well, it turns out that Einstein and Kaluza and many others

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:44.958
worked on trying to refine this framework

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
and apply it to the physics of the universe

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
as was understood at the time, and, in detail, it didn't work.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:52.958
In detail, for instance,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
they couldn't get the mass of the electron

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
to work out correctly in this theory.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:01.958
So many people worked on it, but by the '40s, certainly by the '50s,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
this strange but very compelling idea

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
of how to unify the laws of physics had gone away.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
Until something wonderful happened in our age.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
In our era, a new approach to unify the laws of physics

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
is being pursued by physicists such as myself,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
many others around the world,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
it's called superstring theory, as you were indicating.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
And the wonderful thing is that superstring theory

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.958
has nothing to do at first sight with this idea of extra dimensions,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
but when we study superstring theory,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
we find that it resurrects the idea in a sparkling, new form.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
So, let me just tell you how that goes.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
Superstring theory -- what is it?

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
Well, it's a theory that tries to answer the question:

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:48.958
what are the basic, fundamental, indivisible, uncuttable constituents

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
making up everything in the world around us?

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
The idea is like this.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:59.958
So, imagine we look at a familiar object, just a candle in a holder,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
and imagine that we want to figure out what it is made of.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:06.958
So we go on a journey deep inside the object and examine the constituents.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:10.958
So deep inside -- we all know, you go sufficiently far down, you have atoms.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
We also all know that atoms are not the end of the story.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:17.958
They have little electrons that swarm around a central nucleus

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:18.958
with neutrons and protons.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:23.958
Even the neutrons and protons have smaller particles inside of them known as quarks.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
That is where conventional ideas stop.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
Here is the new idea of string theory.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:33.958
Deep inside any of these particles, there is something else.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
This something else is this dancing filament of energy.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
It looks like a vibrating string --

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
that's where the idea, string theory comes from.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
And just like the vibrating strings that you just saw in a cello

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
can vibrate in different patterns,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
these can also vibrate in different patterns.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
They don't produce different musical notes.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:53.958
Rather, they produce the different particles making up the world around us.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:54.958
So if these ideas are correct,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:59.958
this is what the ultra-microscopic landscape of the universe looks like.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
It's built up of a huge number

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:05.958
of these little tiny filaments of vibrating energy,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
vibrating in different frequencies.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
The different frequencies produce the different particles.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
The different particles are responsible

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
for all the richness in the world around us.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
And there you see unification,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
because matter particles, electrons and quarks,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:27.958
radiation particles, photons, gravitons, are all built up from one entity.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:31.958
So matter and the forces of nature all are put together

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
under the rubric of vibrating strings.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:37.958
And that's what we mean by a unified theory.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
Now here is the catch.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
When you study the mathematics of string theory,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
you find that it doesn't work

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
in a universe that just has three dimensions of space.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
It doesn't work in a universe with four dimensions of space, nor five, nor six.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Finally, you can study the equations, and show that it works

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
only in a universe that has 10 dimensions of space

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
and one dimension of time.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:06.958
It leads us right back to this idea of Kaluza and Klein --

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
that our world, when appropriately described,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
has more dimensions than the ones that we see.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Now you might think about that and say, well,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
OK, you know, if you have extra dimensions, and they're really tightly curled up,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
yeah, perhaps we won't see them, if they're small enough.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
But if there's a little tiny civilization of green people walking around down there,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:30.958
and you make them small enough, and we won't see them either. That is true.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
One of the other predictions of string theory --

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
no, that's not one of the other predictions of string theory.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:37.958
(Laughter)

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
But it raises the question:

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
are we just trying to hide away these extra dimensions,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
or do they tell us something about the world?

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
In the remaining time, I'd like to tell you two features of them.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.958
First is, many of us believe that these extra dimensions

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
hold the answer to what perhaps is the deepest question

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
in theoretical physics, theoretical science.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.958
And that question is this: when we look around the world,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
as scientists have done for the last hundred years,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:09.958
there appear to be about 20 numbers that really describe our universe.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
These are numbers like the mass of the particles,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
like electrons and quarks, the strength of gravity,

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
the strength of the electromagnetic force --

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
a list of about 20 numbers

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
that have been measured with incredible precision,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
but nobody has an explanation

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:27.958
for why the numbers have the particular values that they do.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Now, does string theory offer an answer?

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:31.958
Not yet.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:35.958
But we believe the answer for why those numbers have the values they do

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
may rely on the form of the extra dimensions.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
And the wonderful thing is, if those numbers

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
had any other values than the known ones,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
the universe, as we know it, wouldn't exist.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:47.958
This is a deep question.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
Why are those numbers so finely tuned

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
to allow stars to shine and planets to form,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
when we recognize that if you fiddle with those numbers --

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
if I had 20 dials up here

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
and I let you come up and fiddle with those numbers,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:02.958
almost any fiddling makes the universe disappear.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
So can we explain those 20 numbers?

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
And string theory suggests that those 20 numbers

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
have to do with the extra dimensions.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
Let me show you how.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:15.958
So when we talk about the extra dimensions in string theory,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
it's not one extra dimension,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.958
as in the older ideas of Kaluza and Klein.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
This is what string theory says about the extra dimensions.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
They have a very rich, intertwined geometry.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:31.958
This is an example of something known as a Calabi-Yau shape --

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
name isn't all that important.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
But, as you can see,

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
the extra dimensions fold in on themselves

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:42.958
and intertwine in a very interesting shape, interesting structure.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:47.958
And the idea is that if this is what the extra dimensions look like,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
then the microscopic landscape of our universe all around us

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
would look like this on the tiniest of scales.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:54.958
When you swing your hand,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
you'd be moving around these extra dimensions over and over again,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
but they're so small that we wouldn't know it.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
So what is the physical implication, though, relevant to those 20 numbers?

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
Consider this. If you look at the instrument, a French horn,

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
notice that the vibrations of the airstreams

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
are affected by the shape of the instrument.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
Now in string theory,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
all the numbers are reflections of the way strings can vibrate.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
So just as those airstreams

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
are affected by the twists and turns in the instrument,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
strings themselves will be affected

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
by the vibrational patterns in the geometry within which they are moving.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
So let me bring some strings into the story.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
And if you watch these little fellows vibrating around --

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
they'll be there in a second -- right there,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
notice that they way they vibrate is affected

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
by the geometry of the extra dimensions.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
So, if we knew exactly what the extra dimensions look like --

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
we don't yet, but if we did --

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
we should be able to calculate the allowed notes,

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
the allowed vibrational patterns.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
And if we could calculate the allowed vibrational patterns,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
we should be able to calculate those 20 numbers.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:57.958
And if the answer that we get from our calculations

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
agrees with the values of those numbers

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
that have been determined

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
through detailed and precise experimentation,

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:09.958
this in many ways would be the first fundamental explanation

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:14.958
for why the structure of the universe is the way it is.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
Now, the second issue that I want to finish up with is:

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:22.958
how might we test for these extra dimensions more directly?

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
Is this just an interesting mathematical structure

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
that might be able to explain

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:32.958
some previously unexplained features of the world,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
or can we actually test for these extra dimensions?

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
And we think -- and this is, I think, very exciting --

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:41.958
that in the next five years or so we may be able to test

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
for the existence of these extra dimensions.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:48.958
Here's how it goes. In CERN, Geneva, Switzerland,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:52.958
a machine is being built called the Large Hadron Collider.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:55.958
It's a machine that will send particles around a tunnel,

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
opposite directions, near the speed of light.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
Every so often those particles will be aimed at each other,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
so there's a head-on collision.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:07.958
The hope is that if the collision has enough energy,

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
it may eject some of the debris from the collision

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:15.958
from our dimensions, forcing it to enter into the other dimensions.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:17.958
How would we know it?

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
Well, we'll measure the amount of energy after the collision,

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
compare it to the amount of energy before,

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:26.958
and if there's less energy after the collision than before,

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
this will be evidence that the energy has drifted away.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:31.958
And if it drifts away in the right pattern that we can calculate,

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
this will be evidence that the extra dimensions are there.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
Let me show you that idea visually.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
So, imagine we have a certain kind of particle called a graviton --

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:43.958
that's the kind of debris we expect to be ejected out,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
if the extra dimensions are real.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:46.958
But here's how the experiment will go.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
You take these particles. You slam them together.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
You slam them together, and if we are right,

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
some of the energy of that collision

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:57.958
will go into debris that flies off into these extra dimensions.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
So this is the kind of experiment

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:03.958
that we'll be looking at in the next five, seven to 10 years or so.

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.958
And if this experiment bears fruit,

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:09.958
if we see that kind of particle ejected

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
by noticing that there's less energy in our dimensions

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.958
than when we began,

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
this will show that the extra dimensions are real.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:20.958
And to me this is a really remarkable story,

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:24.958
and a remarkable opportunity. Going back to Newton with absolute space --

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
didn't provide anything but an arena, a stage

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
in which the events of the universe take place.

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
Einstein comes along and says,

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
well, space and time can warp and curve -- that's what gravity is.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:37.958
And now string theory comes along and says,

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
yes, gravity, quantum mechanics, electromagnetism,

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.958
all together in one package,

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:46.958
but only if the universe has more dimensions than the ones that we see.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:51.958
And this is an experiment that may test for them in our lifetime.

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:53.958
Amazing possibility.

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:55.958
Thank you very much.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:19:02.958
(Applause)

title: CERN's supercollider
transcript: This is the Large Hadron Collider. It's 27 kilometers in circumference. It's the biggest scientific experiment ever attempted. Over 10,000 physicists and engineers from 85 countries around the world have come together over several decades to build this machine. What we do is we accelerate protons — so, hydrogen nuclei — around 99.999999 percent the speed of light. Right? At that speed, they go around that 27 kilometers 11,000 times a second. And we collide them with another beam of protons going in the opposite direction. We collide them inside giant detectors.They're essentially digital cameras. And this is the one that I work on, ATLAS. You get some sense of the size — you can just see these EU standard-size people underneath.(Laughter)You get some sense of the size: 44 meters wide, 22 meters in diameter, 7,000 tons. And we re-create the conditions that were present less than a billionth of a second after the universe began up to 600 million times a second inside that detector — immense numbers. And if you see those metal bits there — those are huge magnets that bend electrically charged particles, so it can measure how fast they're traveling. This is a picture about a year ago. Those magnets are in there. And, again, a EU standard-size, real person, so you get some sense of the scale. And it's in there that those mini-Big Bangs will be created, sometime in the summer this year.And actually, this morning, I got an email saying that we've just finished, today, building the last piece of ATLAS. So as of today, it's finished. I'd like to say that I planned that for TED, but I didn't. So it's been completed as of today.(Applause)Yeah, it's a wonderful achievement. So, you might be asking, "Why? Why create the conditions that were present less than a billionth of a second after the universe began?" Well, particle physicists are nothing if not ambitious. And the aim of particle physics is to understand what everything's made of, and how everything sticks together. And by everything I mean, of course, me and you, the Earth, the Sun, the 100 billion suns in our galaxy and the 100 billion galaxies in the observable universe. Absolutely everything.Now you might say, "Well, OK, but why not just look at it? You know? If you want to know what I'm made of, let's look at me." Well, we found that as you look back in time, the universe gets hotter and hotter, denser and denser, and simpler and simpler. Now, there's no real reason I'm aware of for that, but that seems to be the case. So, way back in the early times of the universe, we believe it was very simple and understandable. All this complexity, all the way to these wonderful things — human brains — are a property of an old and cold and complicated universe. Back at the start, in the first billionth of a second, we believe, or we've observed, it was very simple.It's almost like ... imagine a snowflake in your hand, and you look at it, and it's an incredibly complicated, beautiful object. But as you heat it up, it'll melt into a pool of water, and you would be able to see that, actually, it was just made of H20, water. So it's in that same sense that we look back in time to understand what the universe is made of. And, as of today, it's made of these things. Just 12 particles of matter, stuck together by four forces of nature. The quarks, these pink things, are the things that make up protons and neutrons that make up the atomic nuclei in your body. The electron — the thing that goes around the atomic nucleus — held around in orbit, by the way, by the electromagnetic force that's carried by this thing, the photon. The quarks are stuck together by other things called gluons.And these guys, here, they're the weak nuclear force, probably the least familiar. But, without it, the sun wouldn't shine. And when the sun shines, you get copious quantities of these things, called neutrinos, pouring out. Actually, if you just look at your thumbnail — about a square centimeter — there are something like 60 billion neutrinos per second from the sun, passing through every square centimeter of your body. But you don't feel them, because the weak force is correctly named — very short range and very weak, so they just fly through you.And these particles have been discovered over the last century, pretty much. The first one, the electron, was discovered in 1897, and the last one, this thing called the tau neutrino, in the year 2000. Actually just — I was going to say, just up the road in Chicago. I know it's a big country, America, isn't it? Just up the road. Relative to the universe, it's just up the road.(Laughter)So, this thing was discovered in the year 2000, so it's a relatively recent picture. One of the wonderful things, actually, I find, is that we've discovered any of them, when you realize how tiny they are. You know, they're a step in size from the entire observable universe. So, 100 billion galaxies, 13.7 billion light years away — a step in size from that to Monterey, actually, is about the same as from Monterey to these things. Absolutely, exquisitely minute, and yet we've discovered pretty much the full set.So, one of my most illustrious forebears at Manchester University, Ernest Rutherford, discoverer of the atomic nucleus, once said, "All science is either physics or stamp collecting." Now, I don't think he meant to insult the rest of science, although he was from New Zealand, so it's possible.(Laughter)But what he meant was that what we've done, really, is stamp collect there. OK, we've discovered the particles, but unless you understand the underlying reason for that pattern — you know, why it's built the way it is — really you've done stamp collecting. You haven't done science. Fortunately, we have probably one of the greatest scientific achievements of the twentieth century that underpins that pattern. It's the Newton's laws, if you want, of particle physics. It's called the standard model — beautifully simple mathematical equation. You could stick it on the front of a T-shirt, which is always the sign of elegance. This is it.(Laughter)I've been a little disingenuous, because I've expanded it out in all its gory detail. This equation, though, allows you to calculate everything — other than gravity — that happens in the universe. So, you want to know why the sky is blue, why atomic nuclei stick together — in principle, you've got a big enough computer — why DNA is the shape it is. In principle, you should be able to calculate it from that equation.But there's a problem. Can anyone see what it is? A bottle of champagne for anyone that tells me. I'll make it easier, actually, by blowing one of the lines up. Basically, each of these terms refers to some of the particles. So those Ws there refer to the Ws, and how they stick together. These carriers of the weak force, the Zs, the same. But there's an extra symbol in this equation: H. Right, H. H stands for Higgs particle. Higgs particles have not been discovered. But they're necessary: they're necessary to make that mathematics work. So all the exquisitely detailed calculations we can do with that wonderful equation wouldn't be possible without an extra bit. So it's a prediction: a prediction of a new particle.What does it do? Well, we had a long time to come up with good analogies. And back in the 1980s, when we wanted the money for the LHC from the U.K. government, Margaret Thatcher, at the time, said, "If you guys can explain, in language a politician can understand, what the hell it is that you're doing, you can have the money. I want to know what this Higgs particle does." And we came up with this analogy, and it seemed to work. Well, what the Higgs does is, it gives mass to the fundamental particles. And the picture is that the whole universe — and that doesn't mean just space, it means me as well, and inside you — the whole universe is full of something called a Higgs field. Higgs particles, if you will.The analogy is that these people in a room are the Higgs particles. Now when a particle moves through the universe, it can interact with these Higgs particles. But imagine someone who's not very popular moves through the room. Then everyone ignores them. They can just pass through the room very quickly, essentially at the speed of light. They're massless. And imagine someone incredibly important and popular and intelligent walks into the room. They're surrounded by people, and their passage through the room is impeded. It's almost like they get heavy. They get massive. And that's exactly the way the Higgs mechanism works. The picture is that the electrons and the quarks in your body and in the universe that we see around us are heavy, in a sense, and massive, because they're surrounded by Higgs particles. They're interacting with the Higgs field.If that picture's true, then we have to discover those Higgs particles at the LHC. If it's not true — because it's quite a convoluted mechanism, although it's the simplest we've been able to think of — then whatever does the job of the Higgs particles we know have to turn up at the LHC. So, that's one of the prime reasons we built this giant machine. I'm glad you recognize Margaret Thatcher. Actually, I thought about making it more culturally relevant, but — (Laughter) anyway. So that's one thing. That's essentially a guarantee of what the LHC will find.There are many other things. You've heard many of the big problems in particle physics. One of them you heard about: dark matter, dark energy. There's another issue, which is that the forces in nature — it's quite beautiful, actually — seem, as you go back in time, they seem to change in strength. Well, they do change in strength. So, the electromagnetic force, the force that holds us together, gets stronger as you go to higher temperatures. The strong force, the strong nuclear force, which sticks nuclei together, gets weaker. And what you see is the standard model — you can calculate how these change — is the forces, the three forces, other than gravity, almost seem to come together at one point. It's almost as if there was one beautiful kind of super-force, back at the beginning of time. But they just miss.Now there's a theory called super-symmetry, which doubles the number of particles in the standard model, which, at first sight, doesn't sound like a simplification. But actually, with this theory, we find that the forces of nature do seem to unify together, back at the Big Bang — absolutely beautiful prophecy. The model wasn't built to do that, but it seems to do it. Also, those super-symmetric particles are very strong candidates for the dark matter. So a very compelling theory that's really mainstream physics. And if I was to put money on it, I would put money on — in a very unscientific way — that that these things would also crop up at the LHC. Many other things that the LHC could discover.But in the last few minutes, I just want to give you a different perspective of what I think — what particle physics really means to me — particle physics and cosmology. And that's that I think it's given us a wonderful narrative — almost a creation story, if you'd like — about the universe, from modern science over the last few decades. And I'd say that it deserves, in the spirit of Wade Davis' talk, to be at least put up there with these wonderful creation stories of the peoples of the high Andes and the frozen north. This is a creation story, I think, equally as wonderful.The story goes like this: we know that the universe began 13.7 billion years ago, in an immensely hot, dense state, much smaller than a single atom. It began to expand about a million, billion, billion, billion billionth of a second — I think I got that right — after the Big Bang. Gravity separated away from the other forces. The universe then underwent an exponential expansion called inflation. In about the first billionth of a second or so, the Higgs field kicked in, and the quarks and the gluons and the electrons that make us up got mass. The universe continued to expand and cool. After about a few minutes, there was hydrogen and helium in the universe. That's all. The universe was about 75 percent hydrogen, 25 percent helium. It still is today.It continued to expand about 300 million years. Then light began to travel through the universe. It was big enough to be transparent to light, and that's what we see in the cosmic microwave background that George Smoot described as looking at the face of God. After about 400 million years, the first stars formed, and that hydrogen, that helium, then began to cook into the heavier elements. So the elements of life — carbon, and oxygen and iron, all the elements that we need to make us up — were cooked in those first generations of stars, which then ran out of fuel, exploded, threw those elements back into the universe. They then re-collapsed into another generation of stars and planets.And on some of those planets, the oxygen, which had been created in that first generation of stars, could fuse with hydrogen to form water, liquid water on the surface. On at least one, and maybe only one of those planets, primitive life evolved, which evolved over millions of years into things that walked upright and left footprints about three and a half million years ago in the mud flats of Tanzania, and eventually left a footprint on another world. And built this civilization, this wonderful picture, that turned the darkness into light, and you can see the civilization from space. As one of my great heroes, Carl Sagan, said, these are the things — and actually, not only these, but I was looking around — these are the things, like Saturn V rockets, and Sputnik, and DNA, and literature and science — these are the things that hydrogen atoms do when given 13.7 billion years.Absolutely remarkable. And, the laws of physics. Right? So, the right laws of physics — they're beautifully balanced. If the weak force had been a little bit different, then carbon and oxygen wouldn't be stable inside the hearts of stars, and there would be none of that in the universe. And I think that's a wonderful and significant story. 50 years ago, I couldn't have told that story, because we didn't know it. It makes me really feel that that civilization — which, as I say, if you believe the scientific creation story, has emerged purely as a result of the laws of physics, and a few hydrogen atoms — then I think, to me anyway, it makes me feel incredibly valuable.So that's the LHC. The LHC is certainly, when it turns on in summer, going to write the next chapter of that book. And I'm certainly looking forward with immense excitement to it being turned on. Thanks.(Applause)

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:15.958
This is the Large Hadron Collider.

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:17.958
It's 27 kilometers in circumference.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
It's the biggest scientific experiment ever attempted.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
Over 10,000 physicists and engineers

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:25.958
from 85 countries around the world

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
have come together over several decades

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:29.958
to build this machine.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
What we do is we accelerate protons --

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
so, hydrogen nuclei --

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:37.958
around 99.999999

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
percent the speed of light.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
Right? At that speed, they go around

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.958
that 27 kilometers 11,000 times a second.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
And we collide them with another beam of protons

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
going in the opposite direction.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
We collide them inside giant detectors.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
They're essentially digital cameras.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
And this is the one that I work on, ATLAS.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
You get some sense of the size --

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
you can just see these EU standard-size

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
people underneath.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
(Laughter)

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
You get some sense of the size: 44 meters wide,

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
22 meters in diameter, 7,000 tons.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
And we re-create the conditions that were present

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
less than a billionth of a second after the universe began

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
up to 600 million times a second

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
inside that detector -- immense numbers.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
And if you see those metal bits there --

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
those are huge magnets that bend

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
electrically charged particles,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
so it can measure how fast they're traveling.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
This is a picture about a year ago.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
Those magnets are in there.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
And, again, a EU standard-size, real person,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
so you get some sense of the scale.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
And it's in there that those mini-Big Bangs will be created,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
sometime in the summer this year.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
And actually, this morning, I got an email

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
saying that we've just finished, today,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
building the last piece of ATLAS.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
So as of today, it's finished. I'd like to say

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:53.958
that I planned that for TED,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
but I didn't. So it's been completed as of today.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:02:00.958
(Applause)

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
Yeah, it's a wonderful achievement.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
So, you might be asking, "Why?

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
Why create the conditions that were present

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
less than a billionth of a second after the universe began?"

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
Well, particle physicists are nothing if not ambitious.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
And the aim of particle physics is to understand

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
what everything's made of, and how everything sticks together.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
And by everything I mean, of course,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
me and you, the Earth, the Sun,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
the 100 billion suns in our galaxy

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
and the 100 billion galaxies

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
in the observable universe.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
Absolutely everything.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
Now you might say, "Well, OK, but why not just look at it?

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
You know? If you want to know what I'm made of, let's look at me."

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
Well, we found that as you look back in time,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
the universe gets hotter and hotter,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
denser and denser, and simpler and simpler.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
Now, there's no real reason I'm aware of for that,

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
but that seems to be the case.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
So, way back in the early times of the universe,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
we believe it was very simple and understandable.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:59.958
All this complexity, all the way to these wonderful things --

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
human brains -- are a property of an old

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
and cold and complicated universe.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
Back at the start, in the first billionth of a second,

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
we believe, or we've observed, it was very simple.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
It's almost like ...

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
imagine a snowflake in your hand,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
and you look at it, and it's an incredibly complicated,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
beautiful object. But as you heat it up,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
it'll melt into a pool of water,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
and you would be able to see that, actually, it was just made

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
of H20, water.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
So it's in that same sense that we look back in time

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:32.958
to understand what the universe is made of.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
And, as of today, it's made of these things.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
Just 12 particles of matter,

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
stuck together by four forces of nature.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
The quarks, these pink things, are the things that make up protons and neutrons

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
that make up the atomic nuclei in your body.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
The electron -- the thing that goes around

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
the atomic nucleus --

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.958
held around in orbit, by the way, by the electromagnetic force

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
that's carried by this thing, the photon.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
The quarks are stuck together by other things called gluons.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
And these guys, here, they're the weak nuclear force,

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
probably the least familiar.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
But, without it, the sun wouldn't shine.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
And when the sun shines, you get copious quantities

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
of these things, called neutrinos, pouring out.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
Actually, if you just look at your thumbnail --

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
about a square centimeter --

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
there are something like 60 billion neutrinos per second

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
from the sun, passing

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
through every square centimeter of your body.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
But you don't feel them, because the weak force

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
is correctly named --

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
very short range and very weak,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
so they just fly through you.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
And these particles have been discovered

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
over the last century, pretty much.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
The first one, the electron, was discovered in 1897,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
and the last one, this thing called the tau neutrino,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
in the year 2000. Actually just --

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
I was going to say, just up the road in Chicago. I know it's a big country,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
America, isn't it?

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
Just up the road.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
Relative to the universe, it's just up the road.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
(Laughter)

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
So, this thing was discovered in the year 2000,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
so it's a relatively recent picture.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
One of the wonderful things, actually, I find,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
is that we've discovered any of them, when you realize how tiny they are.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
You know, they're a step in size

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
from the entire observable universe.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
So, 100 billion galaxies,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
13.7 billion light years away --

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
a step in size from that to Monterey, actually,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
is about the same as from Monterey to these things.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
Absolutely, exquisitely minute,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
and yet we've discovered pretty much the full set.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
So, one of my most illustrious forebears

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
at Manchester University, Ernest Rutherford,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
discoverer of the atomic nucleus,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
once said, "All science is either physics

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
or stamp collecting."

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
Now, I don't think he meant to insult

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
the rest of science,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
although he was from New Zealand, so it's possible.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
(Laughter)

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
But what he meant was that what we've done, really,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
is stamp collect there.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
OK, we've discovered the particles,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
but unless you understand the underlying

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
reason for that pattern -- you know, why it's built the way it is --

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
really you've done stamp collecting. You haven't done science.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
Fortunately, we have

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
probably one of the greatest scientific achievements of the twentieth century

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
that underpins that pattern.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
It's the Newton's laws, if you want,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
of particle physics.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
It's called the standard model -- beautifully simple mathematical equation.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
You could stick it on the front of a T-shirt,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
which is always the sign of elegance.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
This is it.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
(Laughter)

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
I've been a little disingenuous, because I've expanded it out

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
in all its gory detail.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
This equation, though, allows you to calculate everything --

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
other than gravity -- that happens in the universe.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
So, you want to know why the sky is blue, why atomic nuclei stick together --

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
in principle, you've got a big enough computer --

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
why DNA is the shape it is.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
In principle, you should be able to calculate it from that equation.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
But there's a problem.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
Can anyone see what it is?

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
A bottle of champagne for anyone that tells me.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
I'll make it easier, actually, by blowing one of the lines up.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
Basically, each of these terms

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
refers to some of the particles.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
So those Ws there refer to the Ws, and how they stick together.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
These carriers of the weak force, the Zs, the same.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
But there's an extra symbol in this equation: H.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
Right, H.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
H stands for Higgs particle.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
Higgs particles have not been discovered.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
But they're necessary: they're necessary

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
to make that mathematics work.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
So all the exquisitely detailed calculations we can do

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
with that wonderful equation

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
wouldn't be possible without an extra bit.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
So it's a prediction:

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
a prediction of a new particle.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
What does it do?

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Well, we had a long time to come up with good analogies.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
And back in the 1980s, when we wanted the money

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
for the LHC from the U.K. government,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
Margaret Thatcher, at the time, said,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
"If you guys can explain, in language

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
a politician can understand,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
what the hell it is that you're doing, you can have the money.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
I want to know what this Higgs particle does."

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
And we came up with this analogy, and it seemed to work.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
Well, what the Higgs does is, it gives mass to the fundamental particles.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
And the picture is that the whole universe --

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
and that doesn't mean just space, it means me as well, and inside you --

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
the whole universe is full of something called a Higgs field.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
Higgs particles, if you will.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
The analogy is that these people in a room

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
are the Higgs particles.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
Now when a particle moves through the universe,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
it can interact with these Higgs particles.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
But imagine someone who's not very popular moves through the room.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
Then everyone ignores them. They can just pass through the room very quickly,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
essentially at the speed of light. They're massless.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
And imagine someone incredibly important

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
and popular and intelligent

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
walks into the room.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
They're surrounded by people, and their passage through the room is impeded.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
It's almost like they get heavy. They get massive.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
And that's exactly the way the Higgs mechanism works.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
The picture is that the electrons and the quarks

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
in your body and in the universe that we see around us

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
are heavy, in a sense, and massive,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
because they're surrounded by Higgs particles.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
They're interacting with the Higgs field.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
If that picture's true,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
then we have to discover those Higgs particles at the LHC.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
If it's not true -- because it's quite a convoluted mechanism,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
although it's the simplest we've been able to think of --

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
then whatever does the job of the Higgs particles

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
we know have to turn up

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
at the LHC.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
So, that's one of the prime reasons we built this giant machine.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
I'm glad you recognize Margaret Thatcher.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
Actually, I thought about making it more culturally relevant, but --

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
(Laughter)

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
anyway.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
So that's one thing.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
That's essentially a guarantee of what the LHC will find.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
There are many other things. You've heard

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
many of the big problems in particle physics.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
One of them you heard about: dark matter, dark energy.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
There's another issue,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
which is that the forces in nature -- it's quite beautiful, actually --

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
seem, as you go back in time,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
they seem to change in strength.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
Well, they do change in strength.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
So, the electromagnetic force, the force that holds us together,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
gets stronger as you go to higher temperatures.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
The strong force, the strong nuclear force, which sticks nuclei together,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
gets weaker. And what you see is the standard model --

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
you can calculate how these change -- is the forces,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
the three forces, other than gravity,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
almost seem to come together at one point.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
It's almost as if there was one beautiful

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
kind of super-force, back at the beginning of time.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
But they just miss.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Now there's a theory called super-symmetry,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
which doubles the number of particles in the standard model,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
which, at first sight, doesn't sound like a simplification.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
But actually, with this theory,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
we find that the forces of nature

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
do seem to unify together, back at the Big Bang --

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
absolutely beautiful prophecy. The model wasn't built to do that,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
but it seems to do it.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
Also, those super-symmetric particles

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
are very strong candidates for the dark matter.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
So a very compelling theory

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
that's really mainstream physics.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
And if I was to put money on it, I would put money on --

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
in a very unscientific way -- that

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
that these things would also crop up at the LHC.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
Many other things that the LHC could discover.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
But in the last few minutes, I just want to give you

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
a different perspective

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
of what I think -- what particle physics

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
really means to me -- particle physics and cosmology.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
And that's that I think it's given us a wonderful

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
narrative -- almost a creation story,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
if you'd like -- about the universe,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
from modern science over the last few decades.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
And I'd say that it deserves,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
in the spirit of Wade Davis' talk,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
to be at least put up there with these wonderful creation stories

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
of the peoples of the high Andes and the frozen north.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
This is a creation story, I think, equally as wonderful.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
The story goes like this: we know that

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
the universe began 13.7 billion years ago,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
in an immensely hot, dense state,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
much smaller than a single atom.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
It began to expand about

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
a million, billion, billion, billion billionth

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:41.958
of a second -- I think I got that right -- after the Big Bang.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
Gravity separated away from the other forces.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
The universe then underwent

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
an exponential expansion called inflation.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
In about the first billionth of a second or so,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
the Higgs field kicked in, and the quarks

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
and the gluons and the electrons

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
that make us up got mass.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
The universe continued to expand and cool.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
After about a few minutes,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
there was hydrogen and helium in the universe. That's all.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
The universe was about 75 percent hydrogen,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
25 percent helium. It still is today.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
It continued to expand

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
about 300 million years.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
Then light began to travel through the universe.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
It was big enough to be transparent to light,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
and that's what we see in the cosmic microwave background

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
that George Smoot described

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
as looking at the face of God.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
After about 400 million years, the first stars formed,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
and that hydrogen, that helium, then began to cook

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
into the heavier elements.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
So the elements of life --

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
carbon, and oxygen and iron,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
all the elements that we need to make us up --

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
were cooked in those first generations of stars,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
which then ran out of fuel, exploded,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
threw those elements back into the universe.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
They then re-collapsed into another generation

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
of stars and planets.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
And on some of those planets, the oxygen, which had been created

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
in that first generation of stars, could fuse with hydrogen

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
to form water, liquid water on the surface.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
On at least one, and maybe only one of those planets,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
primitive life evolved,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
which evolved over millions of years into

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
things that walked upright and left footprints

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
about three and a half million years ago in the mud flats of Tanzania,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
and eventually

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
left a footprint on another world.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
And built this civilization,

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
this wonderful picture,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
that turned the darkness into light,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
and you can see the civilization from space.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
As one of my great heroes, Carl Sagan, said,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
these are the things -- and actually, not only these,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
but I was looking around -- these are the things,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
like Saturn V rockets, and Sputnik,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
and DNA, and literature and science --

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
these are the things that hydrogen atoms do

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
when given 13.7 billion years.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
Absolutely remarkable.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
And, the laws of physics. Right?

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
So, the right laws of physics --

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
they're beautifully balanced.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
If the weak force had been a little bit different,

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
then carbon and oxygen wouldn't be stable

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
inside the hearts of stars,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
and there would be none of that in the universe.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
And I think that's

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
a wonderful and significant story.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
50 years ago, I couldn't have told that story,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
because we didn't know it.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
It makes me really feel that

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
that civilization --

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
which, as I say, if you believe

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
the scientific creation story,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
has emerged purely as a result of the laws of physics,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
and a few hydrogen atoms --

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
then I think, to me anyway,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
it makes me feel incredibly valuable.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
So that's the LHC.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
The LHC is certainly, when it turns on in summer,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
going to write the next chapter of that book.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
And I'm certainly looking forward with

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
immense excitement to it being turned on.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
Thanks.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:46.958
(Applause)
