00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I started juggling a long time ago,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:19.958
but long before that, I was a golfer, and that's what I was, a golfer.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:24.958
And as a golfer and as a kid,

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
one of the things that really sort of seeped into my pores,

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
that I sort of lived my whole life, is process.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
And it's the process of learning things.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:36.958
One of the great things was that my father was an avid golfer, but he was lefty.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
And he had a real passion for golf,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:41.958
and he also created this whole mythology

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
about Ben Hogan and various things.

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
Well, I learned a lot about interesting things

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:49.958
that I knew nothing about at the time, but grew to know stuff about.

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
And that was the mythology of skill.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
So, one of the things that I love to do is to explore skill.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:59.958
And since Richard put me on this whole thing with music --

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
I'm supposed to actually be doing a project with Tod Machover

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
with the MIT Media Lab -- it relates a lot to music.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
But Tod couldn't come and the project is sort of somewhere,

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
I'm not sure whether it's happening the way we thought, or not.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:14.958
But I'm going to explore skill, and juggling,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:20.958
and basically visual music, I guess.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:23.958
OK, you can start the music, thanks.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:04:21.958
(Music)

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
(Applause)

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Thanks. Thank you. Now, juggling can be a lot of fun;

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:37.958
play with skill and play with space, play with rhythm.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
And you can turn the mike on now. I'm going to do a couple of pieces.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
I do a big piece in a triangle

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
and these are three sections from it.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
Part of the challenge was to try to understand rhythm and space

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:52.958
using not just my hands -- because a lot of juggling is hand-oriented --

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
but using the rhythm of my body and feet,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
and controlling the balls with my feet.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
(Applause)

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:28.958
Thanks. Now, this next section was an attempt to explore space.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
You see, I think Richard said something about people that are against something.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:38.958
Well, a lot of people think jugglers defy gravity or do stuff.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
Well, I kind of, from my childhood and golf and all that,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
it's a process of joining with forces.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:45.958
And so what I'd like to do is try to figure out

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
how to join with the space through the technique.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:53.958
So juggling gravity -- up, down.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:57.958
If you figure out what up and down really are,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
it's a complex physical set of skills

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
to be able to throw a ball down and up and everything,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
but then you add in sideways.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:35.958
(Applause)

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:41.958
Now, I look at it somewhat as a way -- when you learn juggling

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:45.958
what you learn is how to feel with your eyes, and see with your hands

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
because you're not looking at your hands,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
you're looking at where the balls are or you're looking at the audience.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:55.958
So this next part is really a way of understanding space and rhythm,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
with the obvious reference to the feet,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:02.958
but it's also time -- where the feet were, where the balls were.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:28.958
(Applause)

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:33.958
Thanks. So, visual music: rhythm and complexity.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
I'm going to build towards complexity now.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:39.958
Juggling three balls is simple and normal.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
(Laughter)

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
Excuse me.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
(Laughter)

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
We're jugglers, OK. And remember, you're transposing,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
you're getting into a subculture here.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:51.958
(Laughter)

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
And juggling -- the balls cross and all that.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
OK, if you keep them in their assigned paths you get parallel lines

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
of different heights, but then hopefully even rhythm.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:05.958
And you can change the rhythm -- good, Michael.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
You can change the rhythm, if you get out of the lights.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:11.958
OK? Change the rhythm, so it's even.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:17.958
Or you can go back and change the height. Now, skill.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:21.958
But you're boxed in, if you can only do it up and down that way.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
So, you've got to go after the space down there.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
OK, then you've got to combine them,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:37.958
because then you have the whole spatial palette in front of you.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
And then you get crazy.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
(Applause)

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
Now, I'm actually going to ask you to try something,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
so you've got to pay attention. Complexity:

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:07.958
if you spend enough time doing something, time slows down

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
or your skill increases, so your perceptions change.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:14.958
It's learning skills -- like being in a high-speed car crash.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
Things slow down as you learn, as you learn, as you learn.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
You may not be able to affect it, it almost drifts on you. It goes.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
But that's the closest approximation I can have to it.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.958
So, complexity. Now, how many here are jugglers?

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
OK, so most of you are going to have a similar reaction to this.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
OK? And whoever laughed there --

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
you understood it completely, right?

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:46.958
(Laughter)

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
No, it looks like a mess. It looks like a mess with a guy there,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
who's got his hands around that mess, OK.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Well, that's what juggling is about, right?

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
It's being able to do something that other people can't do or can't understand.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
All right. So, that's one way of doing it, which is five balls down.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
OK? Another way is the outside.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
And you could play with the rhythm.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
Same pattern.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
Make it faster and smaller.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
Make it wider.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
Make it narrower.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Bring it back up.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
OK. It's done. Thanks.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
(Applause)

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:41.958
Now, what I wanted to get to is that you're all very bright, very tactile.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
I have no idea how computer-oriented or three-dimensionally-oriented you are,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
but let's try something.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:54.958
OK, so since you all don't understand what the five-ball pattern is,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
I'm going to give you a little clue.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:11.958
Enough of a clue? So, you get the pattern, right? OK.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
(Laughter)

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:18.958
You're not getting off that easy. All right?

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:23.958
Now, do me a favor: follow the ball that I ask you to follow.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Green.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
Yellow.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Pink.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
White.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
OK, you can do that? Yeah? OK.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
Now, let's actually learn something.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:44.958
Actually, let me put you in that area of learning, which is very insecure.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
You want to do it? Yeah? OK.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:53.958
Hands out in front of you. Palms up, together.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
What you're going to learn is this.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
(Laughter)

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
OK? So what I want you to do is just listen to me and do it.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
Index finger, middle finger, ring, little.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Little, ring, middle, index. And then open.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:13.958
Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
A little bit faster.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:22.958
(Laughter)

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
All right. A lot of different learning processes going on in here.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
(Laughter)

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
One learning process that I see is this --

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
(Laughter)

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:38.958
OK. Another learning process that I see is this --

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
(Laughter)

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:46.958
OK. So, everybody take a deep breath in, breath out. OK.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
Now, one more time, and --

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:52.958
finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. Open.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. OK.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
Shake your hands out.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
Now, I assume a lot of you spend a lot of time at a computer.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
OK? So, what you're doing is, you're going la, la, la,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
and you're getting this. OK?

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
So that's exactly what I'm going to ask you to do,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
but in a slightly different way. You're going to combine it.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
So what I want you to do is -- fingers.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
I'll tell you what to do with your fingers, same thing.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
But I want you to do is also, with your eyes,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
is follow the colored ball that I ask you to follow.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
(Laughter)

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
OK? Here we go.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
So, we're going to start off looking at the white ball --

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
and I'm going to tell you which color,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
and I'm also going to tell you to go with your fingers. OK?

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
So white ball and --

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:39.958
finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. Pink.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:44.958
Finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger. Green.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
Finger, finger, finger, finger. Yellow.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
Finger, finger, finger, pink or finger.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:55.958
Pink, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger, finger.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
All right.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
(Applause)

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:05.958
How did you do? Well? OK. The reason I wanted you to do this is

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:10.958
because that's actually what most people face throughout their lives,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
a moment of learning, a moment of challenge.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
It's a moment that you can't make sense of.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
Why the hell should I learn this? OK?

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Does it really have anything to do with anything in my life?

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
You know, I can't decipher -- is it fun? Is it challenging? Am I supposed to cheat?

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:26.958
(Laughter)

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
You know, what are you supposed to do?

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:32.958
You've got somebody up here who is the operative principle

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
of doing that for his whole life. OK?

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
Trying to figure that stuff out. But is it going to get you anywhere?

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
It's just a moment. That's all it is, a moment. OK?

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
I'm going to change the script for one second. Just let me do this.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
I don't need music for it. Talking about time in a moment.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
There's a piece that I recently developed which was all about that,

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
a moment. And what I do as a creative artist

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:58.958
is I develop vocabularies or languages of moving objects.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.958
What I've done for you here, I developed a lot of those tricks

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
and I put the choreography together,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
but they're not original techniques.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
Now, I'm going to start showing you some original techniques

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
that come from the work that I've developed. OK?

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
So, a moment, how would you define a moment?

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:17.958
Well, as a juggler, what I wanted to do was create something

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:22.958
that was representational of a moment.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
Ahhh.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
All right, I'm going to get on my knees and do it.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
So, a moment.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:38.958
(Rattling)

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
OK? And then, what I did as a juggler was say,

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
OK, what can I do to make that something

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:47.958
that is dependent on something else, another dynamic.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:18:01.958
(Rattling)

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:06.958
So, a moment.

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
(Rattling)

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
Another moment.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:16.958
(Rattling)

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:21.958
Excuse me, still getting there. A moment that travels.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:26.958
(Rattling)

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:34.958
A moment -- no, we'll try that again. It separates, and comes back together.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
Time. How can you look at time?

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:41.958
And what do you dedicate it to, in exploring a particular thing?

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:44.958
Well, obviously, there's something in here,

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:46.958
and you can all have a guess as to what it is.

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:48.958
There's a mystery. There's a mystery in the moment.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:52.958
And it has to settle. And then it's dependent on something else.

00:18:52.958 --> 00:19:00.958
And then it comes to rest. Just a little thing about time.

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:02.958
Now, this has expanded into a much bigger piece,

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:05.958
because I use ramps of different parabolas that I roll the balls on

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
while I'm keeping time with this.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
But I just thought I'd talk about a moment.

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:13.958
(Applause)

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:19.958
All right. OK. Can we show the video of the triangle?

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:21.958
Are we ready to do that? Yes?

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:23.958
This is the piece that I told you about.

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:27.958
It's a much bigger piece that I do exploring the space of a geometric triangle.

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:26.958
(Applause)

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:31.958
Thanks. The only thing I'll say about the last session is,

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:35.958
you ever try juggling and driving the car with your knees

00:20:35.958 --> 00:20:37.958
at 120 miles an hour?

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:39.958
(Laughter)

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:41.958
The only other thing is, it was a real shock.

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:45.958
I always drove motorcycles. And when I bought my first car, it shocked me

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:50.958
that it cost three times more than my parents' house. Interesting.

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:52.958
Anyway, balance:

00:20:52.958 --> 00:20:58.958
constant movement to find an approach to stillness.

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:00.958
Cheating.

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:02.958
(Laughter)

00:21:03.958 --> 00:21:07.958
Balance: making up the rules so you can't cheat,

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:17.958
so you learn to approach stillness with different parts of your body.

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:28.958
To have a conversation with it. To speak. To listen.

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:29.958
(Laughter)

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:32.958
Hup. Now, it's dependent on rhythm,

00:21:32.958 --> 00:21:39.958
and keeping a center of balance. When it falls, going underneath.

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:42.958
So, there's a rhythm to it.

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:46.958
The rhythm can get much smaller.

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:59.958
As your skill increases, you learn to find those tinier spaces,

00:22:00.958 --> 00:22:04.958
those tinier movements. Thanks.

00:22:04.958 --> 00:22:07.958
(Applause)

00:22:08.958 --> 00:22:10.958

title: A thought experiment on the intelligence of crows
transcript: How many of you have seen the Alfred Hitchcock film "The Birds"? Any of you get really freaked out by that? You might want to leave now.(Laughter)So this is a vending machine for crows. Over the past few days, many of you have been asking, "How did you come to this? How did you get started doing this?" It started, as with many great ideas, or many ideas you can't get rid of, anyway, at a cocktail party. About 10 years ago, I was at a cocktail party with a friend of mine. We were sitting there, and he was complaining about the crows that were all over his yard and making a big mess. And he was telling me we ought to eradicate these things, kill them, because they're making a mess. I said that was stupid, maybe we should just train them to do something useful. And he said that was impossible.And I'm sure I'm in good company in finding that tremendously annoying, when someone tells you it's impossible. So I spent the next 10 years reading about crows in my spare time.(Laughter)And after 10 years of this, my wife said, "You've got to do this thing you've been talking about, and build the vending machine." So I did. But part of the reason I found this interesting is, I started noticing that we're very aware of all the species that are going extinct on the planet as a result of human habitation expansion, and no one seems to be paying attention to all the species that are actually living; they're surviving. And I'm talking specifically about synanthropic species, which have adapted specifically for human ecologies, species like rats and cockroaches and crows.And as I started looking at them, I was finding that they had hyper-adapted. They'd become extremely adept at living with us. And in return, we just tried to kill them all the time.(Laughter)And in doing so, we were breeding them for parasitism. We were giving them all sorts of reasons to adapt new ways. So, for example, rats are incredibly responsive breeders. And cockroaches, as anyone who's tried to get rid of them knows, have become really immune to the poisons that we're using. So I thought, let's build something that's mutually beneficial; something that we can both benefit from, and find some way to make a new relationship with these species. So I built the vending machine.But the story of the vending machine is a little more interesting if you know more about crows. It turns out, crows aren't just surviving with human beings; they're actually thriving. They're found everywhere on the planet except for the Arctic and the southern tip of South America. And in all that area, they're only rarely found breeding more than five kilometers away from human beings. So we may not think about them, but they're always around. And not surprisingly, given the human population growth, more than half of the human population is living in cities now. And out of those, nine-tenths of the human growth population is occurring in cities. We're seeing a population boom with crows. So bird counts are indicating that we might be seeing up to exponential growth in their numbers. So that's no great surprise.But what was really interesting to me was to find out that the birds were adapting in a pretty unusual way. And I'll give you an example of that. This is Betty. She's a New Caledonian crow. And these crows use sticks in the wild to get insects and whatnot out of pieces of wood. Here, she's trying to get a piece of meat out of a tube. But the researchers had a problem. They messed up and left just a stick of wire in there. And she hadn't had the opportunity to do this before. You see, it wasn't working very well. So she adapted.Now, this is completely unprompted; she had never seen this done before. No one taught her to bend this into a hook or had shown her how it could happen. But she did it all on her own. So keep in mind — she's never seen this done.(Laughter)Right.(Laughter)Yeah. All right.(Applause)So that's the part where the researchers freak out.(Laughter)It turns out, we've been finding more and more that crows are really intelligent. Their brains are in the same proportion as chimpanzee brains are. There's all kinds of anecdotes for the different kinds of intelligence they have. For example, in Sweden, crows will wait for fishermen to drop lines through holes in the ice. And when the fishermen move off, the crows fly down, reel up the lines, and eat the fish or the bait. It's pretty annoying for the fishermen.On an entirely different tack, at University of Washington a few years ago, they were doing an experiment where they captured some crows on campus. Some students went out, netted some crows, brought them in, weighed and measured them, and let them back out again. And they were entertained to discover that for the rest of the week, whenever these particular students walked around campus, these crows would caw at them and run around, and make their life kind of miserable.(Laughter)They were significantly less entertained when this went on for the next week. And the next month. And after summer break. Until they finally graduated and left campus, and — glad to get away, I'm sure — came back sometime later, and found the crows still remembered them.(Laughter)So, the moral being: don't piss off crows. So now, students at the University of Washington that are studying these crows, do so with a giant wig and a big mask.(Laughter)It's fairly interesting.(Laughter)So we know these crows are really smart, but the more I dug into this, the more I found that they actually have an even more significant adaptation.Video: Crows have become highly skilled at making a living in these new urban environments. In this Japanese city, they have devised a way of eating a food that normally they can't manage: drop it among the traffic. The problem now is collecting the bits, without getting run over. Wait for the light to stop the traffic. Then, collect your cracked nut in safety.(Laughter)(Applause)Joshua Klein: Yeah, pretty interesting. What's significant about this isn't that crows are using cars to crack nuts. In fact, that's old hat for crows. This happened about 10 years ago in a place called Sendai City, at a driving school in the suburbs of Tokyo. And since that time, all the crows in the neighborhood are picking up this behavior. Now every crow within five kilometers is standing by a sidewalk, waiting to collect its lunch.So they're learning from each other. And research bears this out. Parents seem to be teaching their young. They learn from their peers, they learn from their enemies. If I have a little extra time, I'll tell you about a case of crow infidelity that illustrates that nicely. The point being, they've developed cultural adaptation. And as we heard yesterday, that's the Pandora's box that's getting human beings in trouble, and we're starting to see it with them. They're able to very quickly and very flexibly adapt to new challenges and new resources in their environment, which is really useful if you live in a city.So we know that there's lots of crows. We found out they're really smart and they can teach each other. When all this became clear, I realized the only obvious thing to do is build a vending machine. So that's what we did. This is a vending machine for crows. And it uses Skinnerian training to shape their behavior over four stages. It's pretty simple. Basically, what happens is that we put this out in a field or someplace where there's lots of crows. We put coins and peanuts all around the base of the machine. Crows eventually come by, eat the peanuts, and get used to the machine being there. Eventually, they eat all the peanuts. Then they see peanuts here on the feeder tray, and hop up and help themselves. Then they leave, the machine spits up more coins and peanuts, and life is dandy if you're a crow — you can come back anytime and get yourself a peanut.So when they get really used to that, we move on to the crows coming back. Now they're used to the sound of the machine; they keep coming back and digging out peanuts from the pile of coins that's there. When they get really happy about this, we stymie them.We move to the third stage, where we only give them a coin. Now, like most of us who have gotten used to a good thing, this really pisses them off. So they do what they do in nature when they're looking for something: sweep things out of the way with their beak. They do that here, and that knocks the coins down the slot. When that happens, they get a peanut. This goes on for some time. The crows learn that all they have to do is show up, wait for the coin to come out, put it in the slot, then get their peanut.When they're good and comfortable with that, we move to the final stage, where they show up and nothing happens. This is where we see the difference between crows and other animals. Squirrels, for example, would show up, look for the peanut, go away. Come back, look for the peanut, go away. They do this maybe half a dozen times before they get bored, and then they go off and play in traffic.Crows, on the other hand, show up and they try and figure it out. They know this machine has been messing with them through three different stages of behavior.(Laughter)They figure there must be more to it. So they poke at it and peck at it. And eventually some crow gets a bright idea: "Hey, there's lots of coins lying around from the first stage, hops down, picks it up, drops it in the slot, and we're off to the races. That crow enjoys a temporary monopoly on peanuts, until his friends figure out how to do it, and then there we go.So, what's significant about this to me isn't that we can train crows to pick up peanuts. Mind you, there's 216 million dollars' worth of change lost every year, but I'm not sure I can depend on that ROI from crows.(Laughter)Instead, I think we should look a little bit larger. I think crows can be trained to do other things. For example, why not train them to pick up garbage after stadium events? Or find expensive components from discarded electronics? Or maybe do search and rescue? The main point of all this for me is, we can find mutually beneficial systems for these species. We can find ways to interact with these other species that doesn't involve exterminating them, but involves finding an equilibrium with them that's a useful balance.Thanks very much.(Applause)

00:04:02.048 --> 00:04:04.410
for the different kinds
of intelligence they have.

00:04:04.434 --> 00:04:06.934
For example, in Sweden,
crows will wait for fishermen

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.851
to drop lines through holes in the ice.

00:04:08.875 --> 00:04:10.415
And when the fishermen move off,

00:04:10.439 --> 00:04:13.680
the crows fly down, reel up the lines,
and eat the fish or the bait.

00:04:13.704 --> 00:04:15.642
It's pretty annoying for the fishermen.

00:04:15.666 --> 00:04:17.105
On an entirely different tack,

00:04:17.129 --> 00:04:19.719
at University of Washington
a few years ago,

00:04:19.743 --> 00:04:23.103
they were doing an experiment where
they captured some crows on campus.

00:04:23.127 --> 00:04:25.945
Some students went out,
netted some crows, brought them in,

00:04:25.969 --> 00:04:28.553
weighed and measured them,
and let them back out again.

00:04:28.577 --> 00:04:31.789
And they were entertained to discover
that for the rest of the week,

00:04:31.813 --> 00:04:34.445
whenever these particular students
walked around campus,

00:04:34.469 --> 00:04:36.580
these crows would caw at them
and run around,

00:04:36.604 --> 00:04:38.416
and make their life kind of miserable.

00:04:38.440 --> 00:04:39.442
(Laughter)

00:04:39.466 --> 00:04:41.411
They were significantly less entertained

00:04:41.435 --> 00:04:43.164
when this went on for the next week.

00:04:43.188 --> 00:04:44.461
And the next month.

00:04:44.485 --> 00:04:46.213
And after summer break.

00:04:46.237 --> 00:04:48.536
Until they finally graduated
and left campus,

00:04:48.560 --> 00:04:50.300
and -- glad to get away, I'm sure --

00:04:50.324 --> 00:04:53.563
came back sometime later, and found
the crows still remembered them.

00:04:53.587 --> 00:04:54.593
(Laughter)

00:04:54.617 --> 00:04:56.692
So, the moral being: don't piss off crows.

00:04:56.716 --> 00:04:59.935
So now, students
at the University of Washington

00:04:59.959 --> 00:05:03.331
that are studying these crows,
do so with a giant wig and a big mask.

00:05:03.355 --> 00:05:05.570
(Laughter)

00:05:05.594 --> 00:05:06.904
It's fairly interesting.

00:05:06.928 --> 00:05:08.499
(Laughter)

00:05:08.523 --> 00:05:10.447
So we know these crows are really smart,

00:05:10.471 --> 00:05:12.651
but the more I dug into this,
the more I found

00:05:12.675 --> 00:05:15.840
that they actually have
an even more significant adaptation.

00:05:16.904 --> 00:05:20.318
Video: Crows have become
highly skilled at making a living

00:05:20.342 --> 00:05:22.689
in these new urban environments.

00:05:22.713 --> 00:05:26.624
In this Japanese city, they have devised
a way of eating a food

00:05:26.648 --> 00:05:28.935
that normally they can't manage:

00:05:31.251 --> 00:05:33.061
drop it among the traffic.

00:05:37.261 --> 00:05:42.402
The problem now is collecting the bits,
without getting run over.

00:05:42.426 --> 00:05:44.727
Wait for the light to stop the traffic.

00:05:56.567 --> 00:06:00.033
Then, collect your cracked nut in safety.

00:06:03.660 --> 00:06:04.934
(Laughter)

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.037
(Applause)

00:06:06.061 --> 00:06:08.054
Joshua Klein: Yeah, pretty interesting.

00:06:08.078 --> 00:06:11.015
What's significant about this
isn't that crows are using cars

00:06:11.039 --> 00:06:12.190
to crack nuts.

00:06:12.214 --> 00:06:13.855
In fact, that's old hat for crows.

00:06:13.879 --> 00:06:15.414
This happened about 10 years ago

00:06:15.438 --> 00:06:17.965
in a place called Sendai City,
at a driving school

00:06:17.989 --> 00:06:19.150
in the suburbs of Tokyo.

00:06:19.695 --> 00:06:20.850
And since that time,

00:06:20.874 --> 00:06:23.936
all the crows in the neighborhood
are picking up this behavior.

00:06:23.960 --> 00:06:26.987
Now every crow within five kilometers
is standing by a sidewalk,

00:06:27.011 --> 00:06:28.424
waiting to collect its lunch.

00:06:28.949 --> 00:06:32.019
So they're learning from each other.
And research bears this out.

00:06:32.043 --> 00:06:34.557
Parents seem to be teaching their young.

00:06:34.581 --> 00:06:37.431
They learn from their peers,
they learn from their enemies.

00:06:37.455 --> 00:06:38.910
If I have a little extra time,

00:06:38.934 --> 00:06:41.081
I'll tell you about a case
of crow infidelity

00:06:41.105 --> 00:06:42.543
that illustrates that nicely.

00:06:42.970 --> 00:06:45.638
The point being, they've developed
cultural adaptation.

00:06:45.662 --> 00:06:46.907
And as we heard yesterday,

00:06:46.931 --> 00:06:49.973
that's the Pandora's box
that's getting human beings in trouble,

00:06:49.997 --> 00:06:51.870
and we're starting to see it with them.

00:06:51.894 --> 00:06:54.430
They're able to very quickly
and very flexibly adapt

00:06:54.454 --> 00:06:57.182
to new challenges and new resources
in their environment,

00:06:57.206 --> 00:06:59.451
which is really useful
if you live in a city.

00:07:00.639 --> 00:07:02.721
So we know that there's lots of crows.

00:07:02.745 --> 00:07:05.806
We found out they're really smart
and they can teach each other.

00:07:05.830 --> 00:07:07.131
When all this became clear,

00:07:07.155 --> 00:07:10.318
I realized the only obvious thing to do
is build a vending machine.

00:07:10.342 --> 00:07:11.495
So that's what we did.

00:07:11.519 --> 00:07:13.256
This is a vending machine for crows.

00:07:13.280 --> 00:07:16.947
And it uses Skinnerian training
to shape their behavior over four stages.

00:07:16.971 --> 00:07:18.328
It's pretty simple.

00:07:18.352 --> 00:07:21.356
Basically, what happens
is that we put this out in a field

00:07:21.380 --> 00:07:23.350
or someplace where there's lots of crows.

00:07:23.374 --> 00:07:26.211
We put coins and peanuts
all around the base of the machine.

00:07:26.235 --> 00:07:28.276
Crows eventually come by, eat the peanuts,

00:07:28.300 --> 00:07:30.234
and get used to the machine being there.

00:07:30.258 --> 00:07:32.039
Eventually, they eat all the peanuts.

00:07:32.063 --> 00:07:34.382
Then they see peanuts
here on the feeder tray,

00:07:34.406 --> 00:07:36.128
and hop up and help themselves.

00:07:36.152 --> 00:07:39.025
Then they leave, the machine
spits up more coins and peanuts,

00:07:39.049 --> 00:07:40.819
and life is dandy if you're a crow --

00:07:40.843 --> 00:07:43.289
you can come back anytime
and get yourself a peanut.

00:07:43.313 --> 00:07:46.798
So when they get really used to that,
we move on to the crows coming back.

00:07:46.822 --> 00:07:48.925
Now they're used to the sound
of the machine;

00:07:48.949 --> 00:07:51.061
they keep coming back
and digging out peanuts

00:07:51.085 --> 00:07:52.808
from the pile of coins that's there.

00:07:52.832 --> 00:07:55.368
When they get really happy
about this, we stymie them.

00:07:55.392 --> 00:07:58.186
We move to the third stage,
where we only give them a coin.

00:07:58.210 --> 00:08:00.948
Now, like most of us who have gotten
used to a good thing,

00:08:00.972 --> 00:08:02.311
this really pisses them off.

00:08:02.335 --> 00:08:05.615
So they do what they do in nature
when they're looking for something:

00:08:05.639 --> 00:08:07.712
sweep things out of the way
with their beak.

00:08:07.736 --> 00:08:10.578
They do that here, and that knocks
the coins down the slot.

00:08:10.602 --> 00:08:12.388
When that happens, they get a peanut.

00:08:12.412 --> 00:08:13.707
This goes on for some time.

00:08:13.731 --> 00:08:16.167
The crows learn that
all they have to do is show up,

00:08:16.191 --> 00:08:18.541
wait for the coin to come out,
put it in the slot,

00:08:18.565 --> 00:08:19.716
then get their peanut.

00:08:19.740 --> 00:08:21.819
When they're good
and comfortable with that,

00:08:21.843 --> 00:08:25.014
we move to the final stage,
where they show up and nothing happens.

00:08:25.038 --> 00:08:28.245
This is where we see the difference
between crows and other animals.

00:08:28.269 --> 00:08:31.981
Squirrels, for example, would show up,
look for the peanut, go away.

00:08:32.005 --> 00:08:34.559
Come back, look for the peanut, go away.

00:08:34.583 --> 00:08:37.421
They do this maybe half a dozen times
before they get bored,

00:08:37.445 --> 00:08:39.422
and then they go off and play in traffic.

00:08:39.446 --> 00:08:43.094
Crows, on the other hand,
show up and they try and figure it out.

00:08:43.118 --> 00:08:45.423
They know this machine
has been messing with them

00:08:45.447 --> 00:08:47.469
through three different
stages of behavior.

00:08:47.493 --> 00:08:48.495
(Laughter)

00:08:48.519 --> 00:08:50.298
They figure there must be more to it.

00:08:50.322 --> 00:08:52.131
So they poke at it and peck at it.

00:08:52.155 --> 00:08:54.309
And eventually some crow
gets a bright idea:

00:08:54.333 --> 00:08:58.254
"Hey, there's lots of coins
lying around from the first stage,

00:08:58.278 --> 00:09:02.443
hops down, picks it up, drops it
in the slot, and we're off to the races.

00:09:02.467 --> 00:09:04.887
That crow enjoys a temporary
monopoly on peanuts,

00:09:04.911 --> 00:09:08.554
until his friends figure out
how to do it, and then there we go.

00:09:08.578 --> 00:09:10.934
So, what's significant about this to me

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.292
isn't that we can train crows
to pick up peanuts.

00:09:13.316 --> 00:09:17.146
Mind you, there's 216 million
dollars' worth of change lost every year,

00:09:17.170 --> 00:09:19.825
but I'm not sure I can depend
on that ROI from crows.

00:09:19.849 --> 00:09:20.896
(Laughter)

00:09:20.920 --> 00:09:24.104
Instead, I think we should look
a little bit larger.

00:09:24.128 --> 00:09:26.394
I think crows can be trained
to do other things.

00:09:26.418 --> 00:09:29.894
For example, why not train them
to pick up garbage after stadium events?

00:09:29.918 --> 00:09:32.822
Or find expensive components
from discarded electronics?

00:09:32.846 --> 00:09:34.731
Or maybe do search and rescue?

00:09:35.307 --> 00:09:37.934
The main point of all this for me is,

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.687
we can find mutually beneficial
systems for these species.

00:09:40.711 --> 00:09:43.215
We can find ways to interact
with these other species

00:09:43.239 --> 00:09:45.173
that doesn't involve exterminating them,

00:09:45.197 --> 00:09:48.499
but involves finding an equilibrium
with them that's a useful balance.

00:09:48.523 --> 00:09:49.778
Thanks very much.

00:09:49.802 --> 00:09:55.402
(Applause)

title: How the news distorts our worldview
transcript: How does the news shape the way we see the world? Here's the world based on the way it looks — based on landmass. And here's how news shapes what Americans see. This map — (Applause) — this map shows the number of seconds that American network and cable news organizations dedicated to news stories, by country, in February of 2007 — just one year ago. Now, this was a month when North Korea agreed to dismantle its nuclear facilities. There was massive flooding in Indonesia. And in Paris, the IPCC released its study confirming man's impact on global warming. The U.S. accounted for 79 percent of total news coverage. And when we take out the U.S. and look at the remaining 21 percent, we see a lot of Iraq — that's that big green thing there — and little else. The combined coverage of Russia, China and India, for example, reached just one percent.When we analyzed all the news stories and removed just one story, here's how the world looked. What was that story? The death of Anna Nicole Smith. This story eclipsed every country except Iraq, and received 10 times the coverage of the IPCC report. And the cycle continues; as we all know, Britney has loomed pretty large lately.So, why don't we hear more about the world? One reason is that news networks have reduced the number of their foreign bureaus by half. Aside from one-person ABC mini-bureaus in Nairobi, New Delhi and Mumbai, there are no network news bureaus in all of Africa, India or South America — places that are home to more than two billion people.The reality is that covering Britney is cheaper. And this lack of global coverage is all the more disturbing when we see where people go for news. Local TV news looms large, and unfortunately only dedicates 12 percent of its coverage to international news.And what about the web? The most popular news sites don't do much better. Last year, Pew and the Colombia J-School analyzed the 14,000 stories that appeared on Google News' front page. And they, in fact, covered the same 24 news events. Similarly, a study in e-content showed that much of global news from U.S. news creators is recycled stories from the AP wire services and Reuters, and don't put things into a context that people can understand their connection to it.So, if you put it all together, this could help explain why today's college graduates, as well as less educated Americans, know less about the world than their counterparts did 20 years ago. And if you think it's simply because we are not interested, you would be wrong. In recent years, Americans who say they closely follow global news most of the time grew to over 50 percent.The real question: is this distorted worldview what we want for Americans in our increasingly interconnected world? I know we can do better. And can we afford not to? Thank you.
