Believe it or not, some of us do survive.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:56.958
Some of us do survive malaria; we do survive AIDS.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:03:00.958
And like I tell my family, and my wife reminds me every time,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:04.958
"You're risking your life, you know, every time you go to that country."

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
And she's right. Every time you go there,

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:12.958
you know that if you actually need critical care --

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
critical care of any sort -- if you have an accident --

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
of which there are many, there are accidents everywhere --

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
where do they go?

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:27.958
Where do they go when they need help for this kind of stuff?

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
I'm not saying instead of, I'm saying as well as,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:36.958
AIDS, TB, malaria, typhoid -- the list goes on.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:40.958
I'm saying, where do they go when they're like me?

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
When I go back home -- and I do all kinds of things,

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.958
I teach, I train -- but I catch one of these things,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:53.958
or I'm chronically ill with one of those, where do they go?

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:59.958
What's the economic impact when one of them dies or becomes disabled?

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:03.958
I think it's quite significant. This is where they go.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
These are not old pictures and these are not from some downtrodden --

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:13.958
this is a major hospital. In fact, it's from a major teaching hospital in Nigeria.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:18.958
Now that is less than a year old, in an operating room.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
That's sterilizing equipment in Nigeria.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
You remember all that oil?

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:27.958
Yes, I'm sorry if it upsets some of you, but

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:31.958
I think you need to see this. That's the floor, OK?

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
You can say some of this is education.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:37.958
You can say it's hygiene. I'm not pleading poverty.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:43.958
I'm saying we need more than just, you know, vaccination,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
malaria, AIDS, because I want to be treated

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
in a proper hospital if something happens to me out there.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
In fact, when I start running around saying,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
"Hey, boys and girls, you're cardiologists in the U.S.,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
can you come home with me and do a mission?"

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
I want them to think, "Well there's some hope."

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
Now, have a look at that. That's the anesthesiology machine.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
And that's my specialty, right?

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:08.958
Anesthesiology and critical care -- look at that bag.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:12.958
It's been taped with tape that we even stopped using in the U.K.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
And believe me, these are current pictures.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:20.958
Now, if something like this, which has happened in the U.K.,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:25.958
that's where they go. This is the intensive care unit in which I work.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:30.958
All right, this is a slide from a talk I gave

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
about intensive care units in Nigeria,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:39.958
and jokingly we refer to it as "Expensive Scare."

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:47.958
Because it's scary and it's expensive, but we need to have it, OK?

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
So, these are the problems.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:54.958
There are no prizes for telling us what the problems are, are there?

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
I think we all know. And several speakers before

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:01.958
and speakers after me are going to tell us even more problems.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:05.958
These are a few of them. So, what did I do?

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
There we go -- we're going on a mission.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.958
We're going to do some open-heart surgery. I was the only Brit,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:17.958
on a team of about nine American cardiac surgeons,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
cardiac nurse, intensive care nurse.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:24.958
We all went out and did a mission and we've done three of them so far.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:28.958
Just so you know, I do believe in missions, I do believe in aid

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
and I do believe in charity. They have their place,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:36.958
but where do they go for those things we talked about earlier?

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:41.958
Because it's not everyone that's going to benefit from a mission.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
Health is wealth, in the words of Hans Rosling.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:50.958
You get wealthier faster if you are healthy first.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
So, here we are, mission. Big trouble.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Open-heart surgery in Nigeria -- big trouble.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
That's Mike, Mike comes out from Mississippi.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
Does he look like he's happy?

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:06.958
It took us two days just to organize the place, but hey,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:11.958
you know, we worked on it. Does he look happy?

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
Yes, that's the medical advice the committee chairman says,

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
"Yes, I told you, you weren't going to be able to,

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
you can't do this, I just know it."

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:22.958
Look, that's the technician we had. So yes, you go on, all right?

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:23.958
(Laughter)

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
I got him to come with me -- anesthesia tech -- come with me from the U.K.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:31.958
Yes, let's just go work this thing out.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
See, that's one of the problems we have in Nigeria and in Africa generally.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
We get a lot of donated equipment.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
Equipment that's obsolete, equipment that doesn't quite work,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
or it works and you can't fix it. And there's nothing wrong with that,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
so long as we use it and we move on.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
But we had problems with it. We had severe problems there.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
He had to get on the phone. This guy was always on the phone.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
So what we going to do now?

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
It looks like all these Americans are here and

00:07:56.958 --> 00:08:00.958
yes, one Brit, and he's not going to do anything --

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
he thinks he's British actually, and he's actually Nigerian,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
I just thought about that.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
We eventually got it working, is the truth,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:10.958
but it was one of these. Even older than the one you saw.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
The reason I have this picture here, this X-ray,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:19.958
it's just to tell you where and how we were viewing X-rays.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
Do you figure where that is? It was on a window.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:27.958
I mean, what's an X-ray viewing box? Please.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
Well, nowadays everything's on PAX anyway.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:34.958
You look at your X-rays on a screen and you do stuff with them,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
you email them. But we were still using X-rays,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
but we didn't even have a viewing box!

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
And we were doing open-heart surgery.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
OK, I know it's not AIDS, I know it's not malaria,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958
but we still need this stuff. Oh yeah, echo --

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:50.958
this was just to get the children ready and the adults ready.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
People still believe in Voodoo. Heart disease,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:57.958
VSD, hole in the heart, tetralogies.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
You still get people who believe in it and they came.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:05.958
At 67 percent oxygen saturation, the normal is about 97.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
Her condition, open-heart surgery that as she required,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
would have been treated when she was a child.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:15.958
We had to do these for adults. So, we did succeed and we still do.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
We've done three. We're planning another one in July

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:22.958
in the north of the country. So, we certainly still do open-heart,

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:27.958
but you can see the contrast between everything that was shipped in --

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.958
we ship everything, instruments. We had explosions

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:38.958
because the kit was designed and installed by people who weren't used to it.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
The oxygen tanks didn't quite work right.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
But how many did we do the first one? 12.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
We did 12 open-heart surgical patients successfully.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
Here is our very first patient, out of intensive care,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
and just watch that chair, all right?

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:59.958
This is what I mean about appropriate technology.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:05.958
That's what he was doing, propping up the bed because the bed simply didn't work.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
Have you seen one of those before?

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
No? Yes? Doesn't matter, it worked.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
I'm sure you've all seen or heard this before:

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:17.958
"We, the willing, have been doing so much with so little for so long --

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:18.958
(Applause)

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:22.958
-- we are now qualified to do anything with nothing."

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
(Applause)

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:30.958
Thank you. Sustainable Solutions -- this was my first company.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:35.958
This one's sole aim is to provide the very things that I think are missing.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:39.958
So, we put my hand in my pocket and say, "Guys, let's just buy stuff.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
Let's go set up a company that teaches people, educates them,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
gives them the tools they need to keep going."

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And that's a perfect example of one.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
Usually when you buy a ventilator in a hospital,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
you buy a different one for children,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
you buy a different one for transport. This one will do everything,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
and it will do it at half the price and doesn't need compressed air.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
If you're in America and you don't know about this one, we do,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
because we make it our duty to find out

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:09.958
what's appropriate technology for Africa -- what's appropriately priced,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:13.958
does the job, and we move on. Anesthesia machine:

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
multi-parameter monitor, operating lights, suction.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:20.958
This little unit here -- remember your little 12-volt plug in the car,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
that charges your, whatever, Game Boy, telephone?

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
That's exactly how the outlets are designed.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:31.958
Yes, it will take a solar panel. Yes a solar panel will charge it.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:36.958
But if you've got mains as well, it will charge the batteries in there.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:40.958
And guess what? We have a little pedal charger too, just in case.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
And guess what, if it all fails,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
if you can find a car that's still got a live battery

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:50.958
and you stick it in, it will still work. Then you can customize it.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
Is it dental surgery you want? General surgery you want?

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:59.958
Decide which instruments, stock it up with consumables.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:08.958
And currently we're working on oxygen -- oxygen delivery on-site.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:17.958
The technology for oxygen delivery is not new.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:22.958
Oxygen concentrators are very old technology. What is new,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
and what we will have in a few months, I hope,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
is that ability to use this same renewable energy system

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:34.958
to provide and produce oxygen on site. Zeolite -- it's not new --

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:41.958
zeolite removes nitrogen from air and nitrogen is 78 percent of air.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
If you take nitrogen out, what's left? Oxygen, pretty much.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
So that's not new. What we're doing is applying this technology to it.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.958
These are the basic features of my device, or our device.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
This is what makes it so special.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
Apart from the awards it's won,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
it's portable and it's certified. It's registered, the MHRA --

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:05.958
and the CE mark, for those who don't know, for Europe, is the equivalent

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:09.958
of the FDA in the U.S.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:13.958
If you compare it with what's on the market, price-wise,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:18.958
size-wise, ease of use, complexity ...

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
This picture was taken last year.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
These are members of my graduating class, 1986.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
It was in this gentleman's house in the Potomac,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
for those of you who are familiar with Maryland.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
There are too many of us outside and everybody,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:40.958
just to borrow a bit from Hans -- Hans Rosling, he's my guy --

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:45.958
if the size of the text represents what gets the most attention,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:50.958
it's the problems. But what we really need are African solutions

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
that are appropriate for Africa -- looking at the culture,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.958
looking at the people, looking at how much money they've got.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:02.958
African people, because they will do it with a passion, I hope.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:06.958
And lots and lots of that little bit down there, sacrifice.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
You have to do it. Africans have to do it,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
in conjunction with everyone else.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
Thank you.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
(Applause)

title: The "bottom billion"
transcript: So, can we dare to be optimistic? Well, the thesis of "The Bottom Billion" is that a billion people have been stuck living in economies that have been stagnant for 40 years, and hence diverging from the rest of mankind. And so, the real question to pose is not, "Can we be optimistic?" It's, "How can we give credible hope to that billion people?" That, to my mind, is the fundamental challenge now of development.What I'm going to offer you is a recipe, a combination of the two forces that changed the world for good, which is the alliance of compassion and enlightened self-interest. Compassion, because a billion people are living in societies that have not offered credible hope. That is a human tragedy. Enlightened self-interest, because if that economic divergence continues for another 40 years, combined with social integration globally, it will build a nightmare for our children. We need compassion to get ourselves started, and enlightened self-interest to get ourselves serious. That's the alliance that changes the world.So, what does it mean to get serious about providing hope for the bottom billion? What can we actually do? Well, a good guide is to think, "What did we do last time the rich world got serious about developing another region of the world?" That gives us, it turns out, quite a good clue, except you have to go back quite a long time. The last time the rich world got serious about developing another region was in the late 1940s. The rich world was you, America, and the region that needed to be developed was my world, Europe. That was post-War Europe.Why did America get serious? It wasn't just compassion for Europe, though there was that. It was that you knew you had to, because, in the late 1940s, country after country in Central Europe was falling into the Soviet bloc, and so you knew you'd no choice. Europe had to be dragged into economic development.So, what did you do, last time you got serious? Well, yes, you had a big aid program. Thank you very much. That was Marshall aid: we need to do it again. Aid is part of the solution. But what else did you do? Well, you tore up your trade policy, and totally reversed it. Before the war, America had been highly protectionist. After the war, you opened your markets to Europe, you dragged Europe into the then-global economy, which was your economy, and you institutionalized that trade liberalization through founding the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. So, total reversal of trade policy.Did you do anything else? Yes, you totally reversed your security policy. Before the war, your security policy had been isolationist. After the war, you tear that up, you put 100,000 troops in Europe for over 40 years. So, total reversal of security policy. Anything else? Yes, you tear up the "Eleventh Commandment" — national sovereignty. Before the war, you treated national sovereignty as so sacrosanct that you weren't even willing to join the League of Nations. After the war, you found the United Nations, you found the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, you found the IMF, you encouraged Europe to create the European Community — all systems for mutual government support. That is still the waterfront of effective policies: aid, trade, security, governments. Of course, the details of policy are going to be different, because the challenge is different. It's not rebuilding Europe, it's reversing the divergence for the bottom billion, so that they actually catch up. Is that easier or harder? We need to be at least as serious as we were then.Now, today I'm going to take just one of those four. I'm going to take the one that sounds the weakest, the one that's just motherhood and apple pie — governments, mutual systems of support for governments — and I'm going to show you one idea in how we could do something to strengthen governance, and I'm going to show you that that is enormously important now. The opportunity we're going to look to is a genuine basis for optimism about the bottom billion, and that is the commodity booms. The commodity booms are pumping unprecedented amounts of money into many, though not all, of the countries of the bottom billion. Partly, they're pumping money in because commodity prices are high, but it's not just that. There's also a range of new discoveries. Uganda has just discovered oil, in about the most disastrous location on Earth; Ghana has discovered oil; Guinea has got a huge new exploitation of iron ore coming out of the ground. So, a mass of new discoveries. Between them, these new revenue flows dwarf aid. Just to give you one example: Angola alone is getting 50 billion dollars a year in oil revenue. The entire aid flows to the 60 countries of the bottom billion last year were 34 billion. So, the flow of resources from the commodity booms to the bottom billion are without precedent. So there's the optimism.The question is, how is it going to help their development? It's a huge opportunity for transformational development. Will it be taken? So, here comes a bit of science, and this is a bit of science I've done since "The Bottom Billion," so it's new. I've looked to see what is the relationship between higher commodity prices of exports, and the growth of commodity-exporting countries. And I've looked globally, I've taken all the countries in the world for the last 40 years, and looked to see what the relationship is. And the short run — say, the first five to seven years — is just great. In fact, it's hunky dory: everything goes up. You get more money because your terms of trade have improved, but also that drives up output across the board. So GDP goes up a lot — fantastic! That's the short run. And how about the long run? Come back 15 years later. Well, the short run, it's hunky dory, but the long run, it's humpty dumpty. You go up in the short run, but then most societies historically have ended up worse than if they'd had no booms at all. That is not a forecast about how commodity prices go; it's a forecast of the consequences, the long-term consequences, for growth of an increase in prices.So, what goes wrong? Why is there this "resource curse," as it's called? And again, I've looked at that, and it turns out that the critical issue is the level of governance, the initial level of economic governance, when the resource booms accrue. In fact, if you've got good enough governance, there is no resource boom. You go up in the short term, and then you go up even more in the long term. That's Norway, the richest country in Europe. It's Australia. It's Canada. The resource curse is entirely confined to countries below a threshold of governance. They still go up in the short run. That's what we're seeing across the bottom billion at the moment. The best growth rates they've had — ever. And the question is whether the short run will persist. And with bad governance historically, over the last 40 years, it hasn't. It's countries like Nigeria, which are worse off than if they'd never had oil.So, there's a threshold level above which you go up in the long term, and below which you go down. Just to benchmark that threshold, it's about the governance level of Portugal in the mid 1980s. So, the question is, are the bottom billion above or below that threshold? Now, there's one big change since the commodity booms of the 1970s, and that is the spread of democracy. So I thought, well, maybe that is the thing which has transformed governance in the bottom billion. Maybe we can be more optimistic because of the spread of democracy. So, I looked. Democracy does have significant effects — and unfortunately, they're adverse. Democracies make even more of a mess of these resource booms than autocracies.At that stage I just wanted to abandon the research, but — (Laughter) — it turns out that democracy is a little bit more complicated than that. Because there are two distinct aspects of democracy: there's electoral competition, which determines how you acquire power, and there are checks and balances, which determine how you use power. It turns out that electoral competition is the thing that's doing the damage with democracy, whereas strong checks and balances make resource booms good. And so, what the countries of the bottom billion need is very strong checks and balances. They haven't got them. They got instant democracy in the 1990s: elections without checks and balances.How can we help improve governance and introduce checks and balances? In all the societies of the bottom billion, there are intense struggles to do just that. The simple proposal is that we should have some international standards, which will be voluntary, but which would spell out the key decision points that need to be taken in order to harness these resource revenues. We know these international standards work because we've already got one. It's called the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative. That is the very simple idea that governments should report to their citizens what revenues they have. No sooner was it proposed than reformers in Nigeria adopted it, pushed it and published the revenues in the paper. Nigerian newspapers circulations spiked. People wanted to know what their government was getting in terms of revenue.So, we know it works. What would the content be of these international standards? I can't go through all of them, but I'll give you an example. The first is how to take the resources out of the ground — the economic processes, taking the resources out of the ground and putting assets on top of the ground. And the first step in that is selling the rights to resource extraction. You know how rights to resource extraction are being sold at the moment, how they've been sold over the last 40 years? A company flies in, does a deal with a minister. And that's great for the company, and it's quite often great for the minister — (Laughter) — and it's not great for their country. There's a very simple institutional technology which can transform that, and it's called verified auctions. The public agency with the greatest expertise on Earth is of course the treasury — that is, the British Treasury. And the British Treasury decided that it would sell the rights to third-generation mobile phones by working out what those rights were worth. They worked out they were worth two billion pounds. Just in time, a set of economists got there and said, "Why not try an auction? It'll reveal the value." It went for 20 billion pounds through auction. If the British Treasury can be out by a factor of 10, think what the ministry of finance in Sierra Leone is going to be like. (Laughter) When I put that to the President of Sierra Leone, the next day he asked the World Bank to send him a team to give expertise on how to conduct auctions.There are five such decision points; each one needs an international standard. If we could do it, we would change the world. We would be helping the reformers in these societies, who are struggling for change. That's our modest role. We cannot change these societies, but we can help the people in these societies who are struggling and usually failing, because the odds are so stacked against them. And yet, we've not got these rules. If you think about it, the cost of promulgating international rules is zilch — nothing. Why on Earth are they not there? I realized that the reason they're not there is that until we have a critical mass of informed citizens in our own societies, politicians will get away with gestures. That unless we have an informed society, what politicians do, especially in relation to Africa, is gestures: things that look good, but don't work. And so I realized we had to go through the business of building an informed citizenry.That's why I broke all the professional rules of conduct for an economist, and I wrote an economics book that you could read on a beach. (Laughter). However, I have to say, the process of communication does not come naturally to me. This is why I'm on this stage, but it's alarming. I grew up in a culture of self-effacement. My wife showed me a blog comment on one of my last talks, and the blog comment said, "Collier is not charismatic — (Laughter) — but his arguments are compelling." (Laughter) (Applause) If you agree with that sentiment, and if you agree that we need a critical mass of informed citizenry, you will realize that I need you. Please, become ambassadors. Thank you. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:15.958
So, can we dare to be optimistic?

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:16.958
Well, the thesis of "The Bottom Billion"

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:21.958
is that a billion people have been stuck living

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:26.958
in economies that have been stagnant for 40 years,

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:30.958
and hence diverging from the rest of mankind.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:33.958
And so, the real question to pose is not, "Can we be optimistic?"

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:38.958
It's, "How can we give credible hope to that billion people?"

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:44.958
That, to my mind, is the fundamental challenge now of development.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
What I'm going to offer you is a recipe,

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:52.958
a combination of the two forces that changed the world for good,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:59.958
which is the alliance of compassion and enlightened self-interest.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:04.958
Compassion, because a billion people are living in societies

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:09.958
that have not offered credible hope.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
That is a human tragedy.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:17.958
Enlightened self-interest, because if that economic divergence

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:22.958
continues for another 40 years,

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:26.958
combined with social integration globally,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:30.958
it will build a nightmare for our children.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:34.958
We need compassion to get ourselves started,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:40.958
and enlightened self-interest to get ourselves serious.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
That's the alliance that changes the world.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:50.958
So, what does it mean to get serious about providing hope for the bottom billion?

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:54.958
What can we actually do?

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.958
Well, a good guide is to think,

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:02.958
"What did we do last time the rich world got serious

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:06.958
about developing another region of the world?"

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:10.958
That gives us, it turns out, quite a good clue,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
except you have to go back quite a long time.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
The last time the rich world got serious

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:21.958
about developing another region was in the late 1940s.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:26.958
The rich world was you, America,

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:31.958
and the region that needed to be developed was my world, Europe.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
That was post-War Europe.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
Why did America get serious?

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:41.958
It wasn't just compassion for Europe, though there was that.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
It was that you knew you had to,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:49.958
because, in the late 1940s, country after country in Central Europe

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:55.958
was falling into the Soviet bloc, and so you knew you'd no choice.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
Europe had to be dragged into economic development.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:02.958
So, what did you do, last time you got serious?

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:06.958
Well, yes, you had a big aid program. Thank you very much.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:11.958
That was Marshall aid: we need to do it again. Aid is part of the solution.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
But what else did you do?

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:21.958
Well, you tore up your trade policy, and totally reversed it.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:25.958
Before the war, America had been highly protectionist.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.958
After the war, you opened your markets to Europe,

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:33.958
you dragged Europe into the then-global economy, which was your economy,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
and you institutionalized that trade liberalization

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:39.958
through founding the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
So, total reversal of trade policy.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:43.958
Did you do anything else?

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
Yes, you totally reversed your security policy.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:50.958
Before the war, your security policy had been isolationist.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:56.958
After the war, you tear that up, you put 100,000 troops in Europe

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
for over 40 years.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:03.958
So, total reversal of security policy. Anything else?

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
Yes, you tear up the "Eleventh Commandment" --

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
national sovereignty.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:15.958
Before the war, you treated national sovereignty as so sacrosanct

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
that you weren't even willing to join the League of Nations.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
After the war, you found the United Nations,

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.958
you found the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:30.958
you found the IMF, you encouraged Europe to create the European Community --

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:34.958
all systems for mutual government support.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:40.958
That is still the waterfront of effective policies:

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:44.958
aid, trade, security, governments.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
Of course, the details of policy are going to be different,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
because the challenge is different.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:55.958
It's not rebuilding Europe, it's reversing the divergence

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
for the bottom billion, so that they actually catch up.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:02.958
Is that easier or harder?

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:07.958
We need to be at least as serious as we were then.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:12.958
Now, today I'm going to take just one of those four.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:15.958
I'm going to take the one that sounds the weakest,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
the one that's just motherhood and apple pie --

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
governments, mutual systems of support for governments --

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:25.958
and I'm going to show you one idea

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:30.958
in how we could do something to strengthen governance,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and I'm going to show you that that is enormously important now.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:42.958
The opportunity we're going to look to

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:48.958
is a genuine basis for optimism about the bottom billion,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
and that is the commodity booms.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:57.958
The commodity booms are pumping unprecedented amounts of money

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:03.958
into many, though not all, of the countries of the bottom billion.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:07.958
Partly, they're pumping money in because commodity prices are high,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:14.958
but it's not just that. There's also a range of new discoveries.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Uganda has just discovered oil, in about the most disastrous location on Earth;

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Ghana has discovered oil;

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:27.958
Guinea has got a huge new exploitation of iron ore coming out of the ground.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
So, a mass of new discoveries.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:35.958
Between them, these new revenue flows dwarf aid.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
Just to give you one example:

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:43.958
Angola alone is getting 50 billion dollars a year in oil revenue.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:49.958
The entire aid flows to the 60 countries of the bottom billion last year were 34 billion.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:54.958
So, the flow of resources from the commodity booms

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:59.958
to the bottom billion are without precedent.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
So there's the optimism.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
The question is, how is it going to help their development?

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:09.958
It's a huge opportunity for transformational development.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
Will it be taken?

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
So, here comes a bit of science, and this is a bit of science I've done

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
since "The Bottom Billion," so it's new.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:22.958
I've looked to see what is the relationship between

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
higher commodity prices of exports,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
and the growth of commodity-exporting countries.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
And I've looked globally, I've taken all the countries in the world

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
for the last 40 years,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
and looked to see what the relationship is.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:44.958
And the short run -- say, the first five to seven years -- is just great.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:49.958
In fact, it's hunky dory: everything goes up.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
You get more money because your terms of trade have improved,

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
but also that drives up output across the board.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:08:00.958
So GDP goes up a lot -- fantastic! That's the short run.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
And how about the long run?

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
Come back 15 years later.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
Well, the short run, it's hunky dory,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:12.958
but the long run, it's humpty dumpty.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:16.958
You go up in the short run, but then most societies

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:21.958
historically have ended up worse than if they'd had no booms at all.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:25.958
That is not a forecast about how commodity prices go;

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
it's a forecast of the consequences, the long-term consequences,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:34.958
for growth of an increase in prices.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:39.958
So, what goes wrong? Why is there this "resource curse," as it's called?

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
And again, I've looked at that, and it turns out

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958
that the critical issue is the level of governance,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
the initial level of economic governance,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
when the resource booms accrue.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
In fact, if you've got good enough governance,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
there is no resource boom.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:09:00.958
You go up in the short term, and then you go up even more in the long term.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:06.958
That's Norway, the richest country in Europe. It's Australia. It's Canada.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
The resource curse is entirely confined to countries

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
below a threshold of governance.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
They still go up in the short run.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
That's what we're seeing across the bottom billion at the moment.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
The best growth rates they've had -- ever.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:25.958
And the question is whether the short run will persist.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
And with bad governance historically, over the last 40 years, it hasn't.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:37.958
It's countries like Nigeria, which are worse off than if they'd never had oil.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:42.958
So, there's a threshold level above which you go up in the long term,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
and below which you go down.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
Just to benchmark that threshold,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:53.958
it's about the governance level of Portugal in the mid 1980s.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:58.958
So, the question is, are the bottom billion above or below that threshold?

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Now, there's one big change since the commodity booms of the 1970s,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
and that is the spread of democracy.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
So I thought, well, maybe that is the thing

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
which has transformed governance in the bottom billion.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.958
Maybe we can be more optimistic because of the spread of democracy.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:19.958
So, I looked. Democracy does have significant effects --

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
and unfortunately, they're adverse.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:28.958
Democracies make even more of a mess of these resource booms than autocracies.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
At that stage I just wanted to abandon the research, but --

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
(Laughter)

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
-- it turns out that democracy is a little bit more complicated than that.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
Because there are two distinct aspects of democracy:

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:45.958
there's electoral competition, which determines how you acquire power,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:51.958
and there are checks and balances, which determine how you use power.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
It turns out that electoral competition is the thing

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
that's doing the damage with democracy,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:11:00.958
whereas strong checks and balances make resource booms good.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And so, what the countries of the bottom billion need

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
is very strong checks and balances.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
They haven't got them.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
They got instant democracy in the 1990s:

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
elections without checks and balances.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:19.958
How can we help improve governance and introduce checks and balances?

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
In all the societies of the bottom billion,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:26.958
there are intense struggles to do just that.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:31.958
The simple proposal is that we should have some international standards,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:36.958
which will be voluntary, but which would spell out the key decision points

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
that need to be taken in order

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
to harness these resource revenues.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
We know these international standards work

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
because we've already got one.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
It's called the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:54.958
That is the very simple idea that governments should report

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
to their citizens what revenues they have.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
No sooner was it proposed

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:06.958
than reformers in Nigeria adopted it, pushed it and published the revenues in the paper.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
Nigerian newspapers circulations spiked.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
People wanted to know what their government was getting

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
in terms of revenue.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:21.958
So, we know it works. What would the content be of these international standards?

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:26.958
I can't go through all of them, but I'll give you an example.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:30.958
The first is how to take the resources out of the ground --

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
the economic processes, taking the resources out of the ground

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
and putting assets on top of the ground.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:40.958
And the first step in that is selling the rights to resource extraction.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:44.958
You know how rights to resource extraction are being sold at the moment,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
how they've been sold over the last 40 years?

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
A company flies in, does a deal with a minister.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
And that's great for the company,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
and it's quite often great for the minister --

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:55.958
(Laughter)

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
-- and it's not great for their country.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
There's a very simple institutional technology

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
which can transform that,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:07.958
and it's called verified auctions.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:13.958
The public agency with the greatest expertise on Earth

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
is of course the treasury -- that is, the British Treasury.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
And the British Treasury decided that it would sell the rights

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
to third-generation mobile phones

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:24.958
by working out what those rights were worth.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
They worked out they were worth two billion pounds.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Just in time, a set of economists got there and said,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
"Why not try an auction? It'll reveal the value."

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958
It went for 20 billion pounds through auction.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
If the British Treasury can be out by a factor of 10,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
think what the ministry of finance in Sierra Leone is going to be like.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:44.958
(Laughter)

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
When I put that to the President of Sierra Leone,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
the next day he asked the World Bank to send him a team

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:54.958
to give expertise on how to conduct auctions.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
There are five such decision points;

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
each one needs an international standard.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
If we could do it, we would change the world.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.958
We would be helping the reformers in these societies,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
who are struggling for change.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:15.958
That's our modest role. We cannot change these societies,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
but we can help the people in these societies

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
who are struggling and usually failing,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:27.958
because the odds are so stacked against them.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
And yet, we've not got these rules.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
If you think about it, the cost of promulgating international rules

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
is zilch -- nothing.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:41.958
Why on Earth are they not there?

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:45.958
I realized that the reason they're not there

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:51.958
is that until we have a critical mass of informed citizens in our own societies,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
politicians will get away with gestures.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:59.958
That unless we have an informed society,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:05.958
what politicians do, especially in relation to Africa, is gestures:

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
things that look good, but don't work.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
And so I realized we had to go through the business

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
of building an informed citizenry.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:20.958
That's why I broke all the professional rules of conduct for an economist,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
and I wrote an economics book that you could read on a beach.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:28.958
(Laughter).

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:32.958
However, I have to say, the process of communication

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
does not come naturally to me.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.958
This is why I'm on this stage, but it's alarming.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:46.958
I grew up in a culture of self-effacement.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:50.958
My wife showed me a blog comment on one of my last talks,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:56.958
and the blog comment said, "Collier is not charismatic --

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
(Laughter)

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
-- but his arguments are compelling."

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:06.958
(Laughter)

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:13.958
(Applause)

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
If you agree with that sentiment,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:22.958
and if you agree that we need a critical mass of informed citizenry,

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
you will realize that I need you.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
Please, become ambassadors.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Thank you.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:43.958
(Applause)

title: Memes and "temes"
transcript: Cultural evolution is a dangerous child for any species to let loose on its planet. By the time you realize what's happening, the child is a toddler, up and causing havoc, and it's too late to put it back. We humans are Earth's Pandoran species. We're the ones who let the second replicator out of its box, and we can't push it back in. We're seeing the consequences all around us.Now that, I suggest, is the view that comes out of taking memetics seriously. And it gives us a new way of thinking about not only what's going on on our planet, but what might be going on elsewhere in the cosmos. So first of all, I'd like to say something about memetics and the theory of memes, and secondly, how this might answer questions about who's out there, if indeed anyone is.So, memetics: memetics is founded on the principle of Universal Darwinism. Darwin had this amazing idea. Indeed, some people say it's the best idea anybody ever had. Isn't that a wonderful thought, that there could be such a thing as a best idea anybody ever had? Do you think there could? Audience: No. (Laughter) Susan Blackmore: Someone says no, very loudly, from over there. Well, I say yes, and if there is, I give the prize to Darwin.Why? Because the idea was so simple, and yet it explains all design in the universe. I would say not just biological design, but all of the design that we think of as human design. It's all just the same thing happening. What did Darwin say? I know you know the idea, natural selection, but let me just paraphrase "The Origin of Species," 1859, in a few sentences.What Darwin said was something like this: if you have creatures that vary, and that can't be doubted — I've been to the Galapagos, and I've measured the size of the beaks and the size of the turtle shells and so on, and so on. And 100 pages later. (Laughter) And if there is a struggle for life, such that nearly all of these creatures die — and this can't be doubted, I've read Malthus and I've calculated how long it would take for elephants to cover the whole world if they bred unrestricted, and so on and so on. And another 100 pages later. And if the very few that survive pass onto their offspring whatever it was that helped them survive, then those offspring must be better adapted to the circumstances in which all this happened than their parents were.You see the idea? If, if, if, then. He had no concept of the idea of an algorithm, but that's what he described in that book, and this is what we now know as the evolutionary algorithm. The principle is you just need those three things — variation, selection and heredity. And as Dan Dennett puts it, if you have those, then you must get evolution. Or design out of chaos, without the aid of mind.There's one word I love on that slide. What do you think my favorite word is? Audience: Chaos. SB: Chaos? No. What? Mind? No. Audience: Without. SB: No, not without. (Laughter) You try them all in order: Mmm...? Audience: Must. SB: Must, at must. Must, must. This is what makes it so amazing. You don't need a designer, or a plan, or foresight, or anything else. If there's something that is copied with variation and it's selected, then you must get design appearing out of nowhere. You can't stop it. Must is my favorite word there.Now, what's this to do with memes? Well, the principle here applies to anything that is copied with variation and selection. We're so used to thinking in terms of biology, we think about genes this way. Darwin didn't, of course; he didn't know about genes. He talked mostly about animals and plants, but also about languages evolving and becoming extinct. But the principle of Universal Darwinism is that any information that is varied and selected will produce design.And this is what Richard Dawkins was on about in his 1976 bestseller, "The Selfish Gene." The information that is copied, he called the replicator. It selfishly copies. Not meaning it kind of sits around inside cells going, "I want to get copied." But that it will get copied if it can, regardless of the consequences. It doesn't care about the consequences because it can't, because it's just information being copied. And he wanted to get away from everybody thinking all the time about genes, and so he said, "Is there another replicator out there on the planet?" Ah, yes, there is.Look around you — here will do, in this room. All around us, still clumsily drifting about in its primeval soup of culture, is another replicator. Information that we copy from person to person, by imitation, by language, by talking, by telling stories, by wearing clothes, by doing things. This is information copied with variation and selection. This is design process going on. He wanted a name for the new replicator. So, he took the Greek word "mimeme," which means that which is imitated. Remember that, that's the core definition: that which is imitated. And abbreviated it to meme, just because it sounds good and made a good meme, an effective spreading meme. So that's how the idea came about. It's important to stick with that definition.The whole science of memetics is much maligned, much misunderstood, much feared. But a lot of these problems can be avoided by remembering the definition. A meme is not equivalent to an idea. It's not an idea. It's not equivalent to anything else, really. Stick with the definition. It's that which is imitated, or information which is copied from person to person. So, let's see some memes.Well, you sir, you've got those glasses hung around your neck in that particularly fetching way. I wonder whether you invented that idea for yourself, or copied it from someone else? If you copied it from someone else, it's a meme. And what about, oh, I can't see any interesting memes here. All right everyone, who's got some interesting memes for me? Oh, well, your earrings, I don't suppose you invented the idea of earrings. You probably went out and bought them. There are plenty more in the shops. That's something that's passed on from person to person. All the stories that we're telling — well, of course, TED is a great meme-fest, masses of memes.The way to think about memes, though, is to think, why do they spread? They're selfish information, they will get copied, if they can. But some of them will be copied because they're good, or true, or useful, or beautiful. Some of them will be copied even though they're not. Some, it's quite hard to tell why.There's one particular curious meme which I rather enjoy. And I'm glad to say, as I expected, I found it when I came here, and I'm sure all of you found it, too. You go to your nice, posh, international hotel somewhere, and you come in and you put down your clothes and you go to the bathroom, and what do you see? Audience: Bathroom soap. SB: Pardon? Audience: Soap. SB: Soap, yeah. What else do you see? Audience: (Inaudible) SB: Mmm mmm. Audience: Sink, toilet! SB: Sink, toilet, yes, these are all memes, they're all memes, but they're sort of useful ones, and then there's this one. (Laughter) What is this one doing? (Laughter) This has spread all over the world. It's not surprising that you all found it when you arrived in your bathrooms here. But I took this photograph in a toilet at the back of a tent in the eco-camp in the jungle in Assam. (Laughter) Who folded that thing up there, and why? (Laughter) Some people get carried away. (Laughter) Other people are just lazy and make mistakes. Some hotels exploit the opportunity to put even more memes with a little sticker. (Laughter) What is this all about? I suppose it's there to tell you that somebody's cleaned the place, and it's all lovely. And you know, actually, all it tells you is that another person has potentially spread germs from place to place. (Laughter)So, think of it this way. Imagine a world full of brains and far more memes than can possibly find homes. The memes are all trying to get copied — trying, in inverted commas — i.e., that's the shorthand for, if they can get copied, they will. They're using you and me as their propagating, copying machinery, and we are the meme machines.Now, why is this important? Why is this useful, or what does it tell us? It gives us a completely new view of human origins and what it means to be human, all conventional theories of cultural evolution, of the origin of humans, and what makes us so different from other species. All other theories explaining the big brain, and language, and tool use and all these things that make us unique, are based upon genes. Language must have been useful for the genes. Tool use must have enhanced our survival, mating and so on. It always comes back, as Richard Dawkins complained all that long time ago, it always comes back to genes.The point of memetics is to say, "Oh no, it doesn't." There are two replicators now on this planet. From the moment that our ancestors, perhaps two and a half million years ago or so, began imitating, there was a new copying process. Copying with variation and selection. A new replicator was let loose, and it could never be — right from the start — it could never be that human beings who let loose this new creature, could just copy the useful, beautiful, true things, and not copy the other things. While their brains were having an advantage from being able to copy — lighting fires, keeping fires going, new techniques of hunting, these kinds of things — inevitably they were also copying putting feathers in their hair, or wearing strange clothes, or painting their faces, or whatever.So, you get an arms race between the genes which are trying to get the humans to have small economical brains and not waste their time copying all this stuff, and the memes themselves, like the sounds that people made and copied — in other words, what turned out to be language — competing to get the brains to get bigger and bigger. So, the big brain, on this theory, is driven by the memes.This is why, in "The Meme Machine," I called it memetic drive. As the memes evolve, as they inevitably must, they drive a bigger brain that is better at copying the memes that are doing the driving. This is why we've ended up with such peculiar brains, that we like religion, and music, and art. Language is a parasite that we've adapted to, not something that was there originally for our genes, on this view. And like most parasites, it can begin dangerous, but then it coevolves and adapts, and we end up with a symbiotic relationship with this new parasite.And so, from our perspective, we don't realize that that's how it began. So, this is a view of what humans are. All other species on this planet are gene machines only, they don't imitate at all well, hardly at all. We alone are gene machines and meme machines as well. The memes took a gene machine and turned it into a meme machine.But that's not all. We have a new kind of memes now. I've been wondering for a long time, since I've been thinking about memes a lot, is there a difference between the memes that we copy — the words we speak to each other, the gestures we copy, the human things — and all these technological things around us? I have always, until now, called them all memes, but I do honestly think now we need a new word for technological memes.Let's call them techno-memes or temes. Because the processes are getting different. We began, perhaps 5,000 years ago, with writing. We put the storage of memes out there on a clay tablet, but in order to get true temes and true teme machines, you need to get the variation, the selection and the copying, all done outside of humans. And we're getting there. We're at this extraordinary point where we're nearly there, that there are machines like that. And indeed, in the short time I've already been at TED, I see we're even closer than I thought we were before.So actually, now the temes are forcing our brains to become more like teme machines. Our children are growing up very quickly learning to read, learning to use machinery. We're going to have all kinds of implants, drugs that force us to stay awake all the time. We'll think we're choosing these things, but the temes are making us do it. So, we're at this cusp now of having a third replicator on our planet. Now, what about what else is going on out there in the universe? Is there anyone else out there? People have been asking this question for a long time. We've been asking it here at TED already. In 1961, Frank Drake made his famous equation, but I think he concentrated on the wrong things. It's been very productive, that equation. He wanted to estimate N, the number of communicative civilizations out there in our galaxy, and he included in there the rate of star formation, the rate of planets, but crucially, intelligence.I think that's the wrong way to think about it. Intelligence appears all over the place, in all kinds of guises. Human intelligence is only one kind of a thing. But what's really important is the replicators you have and the levels of replicators, one feeding on the one before. So, I would suggest that we don't think intelligence, we think replicators.And on that basis, I've suggested a different kind of equation. A very simple equation. N, the same thing, the number of communicative civilizations out there [that] we might expect in our galaxy. Just start with the number of planets there are in our galaxy. The fraction of those which get a first replicator. The fraction of those that get the second replicator. The fraction of those that get the third replicator. Because it's only the third replicator that's going to reach out — sending information, sending probes, getting out there, and communicating with anywhere else.OK, so if we take that equation, why haven't we heard from anybody out there? Because every step is dangerous. Getting a new replicator is dangerous. You can pull through, we have pulled through, but it's dangerous. Take the first step, as soon as life appeared on this earth. We may take the Gaian view. I loved Peter Ward's talk yesterday — it's not Gaian all the time. Actually, life forms produce things that kill themselves. Well, we did pull through on this planet.But then, a long time later, billions of years later, we got the second replicator, the memes. That was dangerous, all right. Think of the big brain. How many mothers do we have here? You know all about big brains. They are dangerous to give birth to, are agonizing to give birth to. (Laughter) My cat gave birth to four kittens, purring all the time. Ah, mm — slightly different. (Laughter)But not only is it painful, it kills lots of babies, it kills lots of mothers, and it's very expensive to produce. The genes are forced into producing all this myelin, all the fat to myelinate the brain. Do you know, sitting here, your brain is using about 20 percent of your body's energy output for two percent of your body weight? It's a really expensive organ to run. Why? Because it's producing the memes.Now, it could have killed us off. It could have killed us off, and maybe it nearly did, but you see, we don't know. But maybe it nearly did. Has it been tried before? What about all those other species? Louise Leakey talked yesterday about how we're the only one in this branch left. What happened to the others? Could it be that this experiment in imitation, this experiment in a second replicator, is dangerous enough to kill people off?Well, we did pull through, and we adapted. But now, we're hitting, as I've just described, we're hitting the third replicator point. And this is even more dangerous — well, it's dangerous again. Why? Because the temes are selfish replicators and they don't care about us, or our planet, or anything else. They're just information, why would they? They are using us to suck up the planet's resources to produce more computers, and more of all these amazing things we're hearing about here at TED. Don't think, "Oh, we created the Internet for our own benefit." That's how it seems to us. Think, temes spreading because they must. We are the old machines.Now, are we going to pull through? What's going to happen? What does it mean to pull through? Well, there are kind of two ways of pulling through. One that is obviously happening all around us now, is that the temes turn us into teme machines, with these implants, with the drugs, with us merging with the technology. And why would they do that? Because we are self-replicating. We have babies. We make new ones, and so it's convenient to piggyback on us, because we're not yet at the stage on this planet where the other option is viable. Although it's closer, I heard this morning, it's closer than I thought it was. Where the teme machines themselves will replicate themselves. That way, it wouldn't matter if the planet's climate was utterly destabilized, and it was no longer possible for humans to live here. Because those teme machines, they wouldn't need — they're not squishy, wet, oxygen-breathing, warmth-requiring creatures. They could carry on without us.So, those are the two possibilities. The second, I don't think we're that close. It's coming, but we're not there yet. The first, it's coming too. But the damage that is already being done to the planet is showing us how dangerous the third point is, that third danger point, getting a third replicator. And will we get through this third danger point, like we got through the second and like we got through the first? Maybe we will, maybe we won't. I have no idea. (Applause) Chris Anderson: That was an incredible talk. SB: Thank you. I scared myself. CA: (Laughter)
