00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
in that particularly fetching way.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
I wonder whether you invented that idea for yourself,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
or copied it from someone else?

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
If you copied it from someone else, it's a meme.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
And what about, oh, I can't see any interesting memes here.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
All right everyone, who's got some interesting memes for me?

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
Oh, well, your earrings,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
I don't suppose you invented the idea of earrings.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
You probably went out and bought them.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
There are plenty more in the shops.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
That's something that's passed on from person to person.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
All the stories that we're telling -- well, of course,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.958
TED is a great meme-fest, masses of memes.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
The way to think about memes, though,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
is to think, why do they spread?

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:07.958
They're selfish information, they will get copied, if they can.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
But some of them will be copied because they're good,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
or true, or useful, or beautiful.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
Some of them will be copied even though they're not.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
Some, it's quite hard to tell why.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
There's one particular curious meme which I rather enjoy.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
And I'm glad to say, as I expected, I found it when I came here,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and I'm sure all of you found it, too.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
You go to your nice, posh, international hotel somewhere,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
and you come in and you put down your clothes

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
and you go to the bathroom, and what do you see?

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Audience: Bathroom soap.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:36.958
SB: Pardon?

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:37.958
Audience: Soap.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
SB: Soap, yeah. What else do you see?

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:40.958
Audience: (Inaudible)

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:41.958
SB: Mmm mmm.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:42.958
Audience: Sink, toilet!

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
SB: Sink, toilet, yes, these are all memes, they're all memes,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
but they're sort of useful ones, and then there's this one.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
(Laughter)

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
What is this one doing?

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:54.958
(Laughter)

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
This has spread all over the world.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
It's not surprising that you all found it

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
when you arrived in your bathrooms here.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:05.958
But I took this photograph in a toilet at the back of a tent

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
in the eco-camp in the jungle in Assam.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:08.958
(Laughter)

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
Who folded that thing up there, and why?

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:13.958
(Laughter)

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
Some people get carried away.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
(Laughter)

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
Other people are just lazy and make mistakes.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
Some hotels exploit the opportunity to put even more memes

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
with a little sticker.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:28.958
(Laughter)

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
What is this all about?

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
I suppose it's there to tell you that somebody's

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
cleaned the place, and it's all lovely.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
And you know, actually, all it tells you is that another person

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
has potentially spread germs from place to place.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:41.958
(Laughter)

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
So, think of it this way.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Imagine a world full of brains

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
and far more memes than can possibly find homes.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
The memes are all trying to get copied --

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
trying, in inverted commas -- i.e.,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
that's the shorthand for, if they can get copied, they will.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:03.958
They're using you and me as their propagating, copying machinery,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
and we are the meme machines.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
Now, why is this important?

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
Why is this useful, or what does it tell us?

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:14.958
It gives us a completely new view of human origins

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:15.958
and what it means to be human,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:19.958
all conventional theories of cultural evolution,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
of the origin of humans,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
and what makes us so different from other species.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
All other theories explaining the big brain, and language, and tool use

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
and all these things that make us unique,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
are based upon genes.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
Language must have been useful for the genes.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
Tool use must have enhanced our survival, mating and so on.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
It always comes back, as Richard Dawkins complained

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
all that long time ago, it always comes back to genes.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
The point of memetics is to say, "Oh no, it doesn't."

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
There are two replicators now on this planet.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
From the moment that our ancestors,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
perhaps two and a half million years ago or so,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
began imitating, there was a new copying process.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Copying with variation and selection.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:07.958
A new replicator was let loose, and it could never be --

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:08.958
right from the start -- it could never be

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:13.958
that human beings who let loose this new creature,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
could just copy the useful, beautiful, true things,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
and not copy the other things.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
While their brains were having an advantage from being able to copy --

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:26.958
lighting fires, keeping fires going, new techniques of hunting,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
these kinds of things --

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
inevitably they were also copying putting feathers in their hair,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
or wearing strange clothes, or painting their faces,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:34.958
or whatever.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:38.958
So, you get an arms race between the genes

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
which are trying to get the humans to have small economical brains

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and not waste their time copying all this stuff,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:48.958
and the memes themselves, like the sounds that people made and copied --

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
in other words, what turned out to be language --

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
competing to get the brains to get bigger and bigger.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:58.958
So, the big brain, on this theory, is driven by the memes.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:02.958
This is why, in "The Meme Machine," I called it memetic drive.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
As the memes evolve, as they inevitably must,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
they drive a bigger brain that is better at copying the memes

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
that are doing the driving.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:15.958
This is why we've ended up with such peculiar brains,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
that we like religion, and music, and art.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
Language is a parasite that we've adapted to,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
not something that was there originally for our genes,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
on this view.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And like most parasites, it can begin dangerous,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
but then it coevolves and adapts,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
and we end up with a symbiotic relationship

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:34.958
with this new parasite.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
And so, from our perspective,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
we don't realize that that's how it began.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
So, this is a view of what humans are.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
All other species on this planet are gene machines only,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
they don't imitate at all well, hardly at all.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:53.958
We alone are gene machines and meme machines as well.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
The memes took a gene machine and turned it into a meme machine.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
But that's not all.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
We have a new kind of memes now.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:03.958
I've been wondering for a long time,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
since I've been thinking about memes a lot,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
is there a difference between the memes that we copy --

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
the words we speak to each other,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
the gestures we copy, the human things --

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
and all these technological things around us?

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:17.958
I have always, until now, called them all memes,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
but I do honestly think now

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
we need a new word for technological memes.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
Let's call them techno-memes or temes.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
Because the processes are getting different.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
We began, perhaps 5,000 years ago, with writing.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:40.958
We put the storage of memes out there on a clay tablet,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
but in order to get true temes and true teme machines,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
you need to get the variation, the selection and the copying,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
all done outside of humans.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
And we're getting there.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
We're at this extraordinary point where we're nearly there,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
that there are machines like that.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
And indeed, in the short time I've already been at TED,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
I see we're even closer than I thought we were before.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:04.958
So actually, now the temes are forcing our brains

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
to become more like teme machines.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
Our children are growing up very quickly learning to read,

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
learning to use machinery.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:12.958
We're going to have all kinds of implants,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
drugs that force us to stay awake all the time.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
We'll think we're choosing these things,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
but the temes are making us do it.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:22.958
So, we're at this cusp now

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
of having a third replicator on our planet.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:32.958
Now, what about what else is going on out there in the universe?

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
Is there anyone else out there?

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
People have been asking this question for a long time.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
We've been asking it here at TED already.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:43.958
In 1961, Frank Drake made his famous equation,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
but I think he concentrated on the wrong things.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
It's been very productive, that equation.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
He wanted to estimate N,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:53.958
the number of communicative civilizations out there in our galaxy,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.958
and he included in there the rate of star formation,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
the rate of planets, but crucially, intelligence.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
I think that's the wrong way to think about it.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
Intelligence appears all over the place, in all kinds of guises.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
Human intelligence is only one kind of a thing.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
But what's really important is the replicators you have

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
and the levels of replicators, one feeding on the one before.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:22.958
So, I would suggest that we don't think intelligence,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
we think replicators.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And on that basis, I've suggested a different kind of equation.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
A very simple equation.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
N, the same thing,

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
the number of communicative civilizations out there

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
[that] we might expect in our galaxy.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:40.958
Just start with the number of planets there are in our galaxy.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
The fraction of those which get a first replicator.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:48.958
The fraction of those that get the second replicator.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
The fraction of those that get the third replicator.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
Because it's only the third replicator that's going to reach out --

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
sending information, sending probes, getting out there,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
and communicating with anywhere else.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
OK, so if we take that equation,

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:07.958
why haven't we heard from anybody out there?

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
Because every step is dangerous.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
Getting a new replicator is dangerous.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
You can pull through, we have pulled through,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
but it's dangerous.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
Take the first step, as soon as life appeared on this earth.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
We may take the Gaian view.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
I loved Peter Ward's talk yesterday -- it's not Gaian all the time.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
Actually, life forms produce things that kill themselves.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
Well, we did pull through on this planet.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
But then, a long time later, billions of years later,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
we got the second replicator, the memes.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
That was dangerous, all right.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Think of the big brain.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
How many mothers do we have here?

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
You know all about big brains.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
They are dangerous to give birth to,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
are agonizing to give birth to.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:51.958
(Laughter)

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
My cat gave birth to four kittens, purring all the time.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Ah, mm -- slightly different.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
(Laughter)

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
But not only is it painful, it kills lots of babies,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
it kills lots of mothers,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
and it's very expensive to produce.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
The genes are forced into producing all this myelin,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
all the fat to myelinate the brain.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
Do you know, sitting here,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:15.958
your brain is using about 20 percent of your body's energy output

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
for two percent of your body weight?

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
It's a really expensive organ to run.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Why? Because it's producing the memes.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:25.958
Now, it could have killed us off. It could have killed us off,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
and maybe it nearly did, but you see, we don't know.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
But maybe it nearly did.

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Has it been tried before?

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
What about all those other species?

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
Louise Leakey talked yesterday

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:37.958
about how we're the only one in this branch left.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
What happened to the others?

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
Could it be that this experiment in imitation,

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
this experiment in a second replicator,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:47.958
is dangerous enough to kill people off?

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
Well, we did pull through, and we adapted.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
But now, we're hitting, as I've just described,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
we're hitting the third replicator point.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
And this is even more dangerous --

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
well, it's dangerous again.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:03.958
Why? Because the temes are selfish replicators

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
and they don't care about us, or our planet, or anything else.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
They're just information, why would they?

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
They are using us to suck up the planet's resources

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
to produce more computers,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
and more of all these amazing things we're hearing about here at TED.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:21.958
Don't think, "Oh, we created the Internet for our own benefit."

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
That's how it seems to us.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:27.958
Think, temes spreading because they must.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
We are the old machines.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
Now, are we going to pull through?

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
What's going to happen?

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
What does it mean to pull through?

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
Well, there are kind of two ways of pulling through.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
One that is obviously happening all around us now,

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:44.958
is that the temes turn us into teme machines,

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:46.958
with these implants, with the drugs,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
with us merging with the technology.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
And why would they do that?

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
Because we are self-replicating.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
We have babies.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
We make new ones, and so it's convenient to piggyback on us,

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:02.958
because we're not yet at the stage on this planet

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
where the other option is viable.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
Although it's closer, I heard this morning,

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
it's closer than I thought it was.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
Where the teme machines themselves will replicate themselves.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:15.958
That way, it wouldn't matter if the planet's climate

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.958
was utterly destabilized,

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
and it was no longer possible for humans to live here.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:21.958
Because those teme machines, they wouldn't need --

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:23.958
they're not squishy, wet, oxygen-breathing,

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:26.958
warmth-requiring creatures.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
They could carry on without us.

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:31.958
So, those are the two possibilities.

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:35.958
The second, I don't think we're that close.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:37.958
It's coming, but we're not there yet.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
The first, it's coming too.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:42.958
But the damage that is already being done

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:47.958
to the planet is showing us how dangerous the third point is,

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
that third danger point, getting a third replicator.

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:53.958
And will we get through this third danger point,

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
like we got through the second and like we got through the first?

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
Maybe we will, maybe we won't.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:02.958
I have no idea.

This is a Gentoo penguin. And she was still skeptical. So, literally, a few minutes before that, I downloaded this scientific paper about calculations on avian defecation, which is really quite interesting, because it turns out you can model this as something called "Poiseuille flow," and you can learn an awful lot about the physics of the avian rectum. Actually, technically, it's not a rectum. It's called a cloaca.At this point, she stops me, and she says, "Who are you? Wha — what do you do?" And I was stuck, because I didn't have any way to describe what I do. And so, in some sense, this talk today is my answer to that. It's a selection of a random bunch of the stuff that I do. And it's very hard for me to make sense of it, so I'm not sure that you can. It's the kind of thing that I sit up late at night thinking about sometimes — often at four in the morning.So, some people are afraid of what I do. Some people think I am the nerd Tony Soprano, and in response, I have ordered a bulletproof pocket protector. I'm not sure what these people think, because I don't speak Norsk.(Laughter)But I'm not thinking "monsteret" is a good thing. I don't know, you know? So, one of the things that I love to do is travel around the world and look at archaeological sites. Because archaeology gives us an opportunity to study past civilizations, and see where they succeeded and where they failed. Use science to, you know, work backwards and say, "Well, really, what were they thinking?"And recently, I was in Easter Island, which is an incredibly beautiful place, and an incredibly mysterious place, because no matter where you go in Easter Island, you're struck by these statues, called the moai. The place is 64 square miles. They made, so far as we can tell, 900 of them. Why on Earth? And if you haven't read Jared Diamond's book, "Collapse," I totally recommend that you do. He's got a great chapter about it. Basically, these people committed ecological suicide in order to make more of these. And somewhere along the line, somebody said, "I know! Let's cut down the last tree and commit suicide, because we need more identical statues."(Laughter)And, one thing that isn't a mystery, actually, was when I grew up — because when I was a little kid, I'd seen these pictures — and I thought, "Well, why that look on the face? Why that brow?" I mean, it's such a powerful thing. Where did they get that inspiration? And then I met Yoyo, who is the native Rapa Nui-an guide, and if you look at Yoyo's face, you kind of figure out where they got it.There's many mysteries, these statues. Everyone wants to know, how did they make them, how did they transport them? This woman in the foreground is Jo Anne Van Tilberg. She's the leading archaeologist working Easter Island today. And she has studied the statues for 20-some years, and she has detailed records of every single statue. The one on the page here is the same that's up there. One interesting problem is the stone isn't very hard. So, this used to be completely smooth. In fact, in many of the statues, when you excavate them, the backs are totally smooth — almost glass smooth. But there's some amazing opportunities in Egypt as well. Another thing I do is I invent stuff. In fact, I design nuclear reactors. Not a joke. This is the conventional nuclear fuel cycle. The red line is what is done in most nuclear reactors. It's called the open fuel cycle. The white lines are what's called an advance fuel cycle, where you reprocess.Now, this is the normal way it's done. It's got the huge advantage that it does not create carbon pollution. It has a lot of disadvantages: each one of these steps is extremely expensive, it's potentially dangerous and they have the interesting property that the step cannot be performed in anyone's backyard, which is a problem. So, our reactor eliminates these steps, which, if we can actually make it work, is a really cool thing. Now, it's kind of nuts to work on a new nuclear reactor. There's — no reactor's been even built to an old design, much less a new one, in the United States for 25 years. It's the kind of very high-risk, but potentially very high-return thing that we do.Changing into a totally different field, we do a lot of stuff in solid state physics, particularly in an area called metamaterials. A metamaterial is an artificial material, which manipulates, in this case, electromagnetic radiation, in a way that you couldn't otherwise. So, this device here is an invisibility cloak. It may not seem that, but if you were a microwave, this is how you would view it. Rays of light — in this case, microwave light — come in, and they just squish around the cell, and they come back the other side. Now, you could do that with mirrors from one angle. The cool thing is, this does it from all angles. Metamaterials, unfortunately — A, it only works on microwave, and B, it doesn't work all that well yet. But metamaterials are an incredibly exciting field. It's — you know, today I'd like to say it's a zero billion dollar business, but, in fact, it's negative. But some day, some day, maybe it's going to work.We do a lot of work in biomedical fields. In this case, we're working with a major medical foundation to develop inexpensive ways of diagnosing diseases in developing countries. E.T.'s phoning home, and I'm not, like, there? You know, horrible! So, I do a lot of work on dinosaurs. I'm known to TEDsters as the guy that has sex with dinosaurs. And I resemble that remark.
