00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
particularly in an area called metamaterials.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:37.958
A metamaterial is an artificial material,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
which manipulates, in this case, electromagnetic radiation,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
in a way that you couldn't otherwise.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
So, this device here is an invisibility cloak.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
It may not seem that, but if you were a microwave,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
this is how you would view it.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Rays of light -- in this case, microwave light --

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
come in, and they just squish around the cell,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
and they come back the other side.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
Now, you could do that with mirrors from one angle.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
The cool thing is, this does it from all angles.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
Metamaterials, unfortunately --

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
A, it only works on microwave,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
and B, it doesn't work all that well yet.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
But metamaterials are an incredibly exciting field.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
It's -- you know, today I'd like to say

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
it's a zero billion dollar business, but,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
in fact, it's negative.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
But some day, some day, maybe it's going to work.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
We do a lot of work in biomedical fields.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
In this case, we're working with a major medical foundation

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
to develop inexpensive ways of diagnosing

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
diseases in developing countries.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
So, they say the eyes are the windows of the soul --

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
turns out they're a window to a whole lot more stuff.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
And these happen to be my eyes, by the way.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
Now, I'm also very interested in cooking.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
While I was at Microsoft, I took a leave of absence

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
and went to a chef school in France.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
I used to work, also while at Microsoft,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
at a leading restaurant in Seattle,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
so I do a lot of cooking.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
I've been on a team that won

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
the world championship of barbecue.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
But barbecue's interesting, because it's one of these cult foods

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
like chili, or bouillabaisse.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
Various parts of the world will have a cult food

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
that people get enormously attached to --

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
there's tremendous traditions, there's secrecy.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
And I'm trying to use a very

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
scientific approach.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
So, this is my latest cooker,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
and if this looks more complicated than the nuclear reactor,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
that's because it is.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
But if you get to play with all those knobs and dials --

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
and of course, really the controller over there does it all on software --

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
you can make some terrific ribs.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
(Laughter)

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
This is a high-speed centrifuge.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
You should all have one in your kitchen,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
beside your Turbochef.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
This subjects food to a force about 50,000 times

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
that of normal gravity,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
and oh boy, does it clarify chicken stock.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
You would not believe it!

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
I perform a series of ghoulish experiments

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
on food --

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
in this case, trying to calibrate a mathematical model

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
so that one can predict exactly

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
what the internal cooking times are.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
It turns out, A, it's useful, and for a geek like me, it's fun.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
Theory is red,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
black is experiment.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
So, I'm either really good at faking it,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
or this particular model seems to work.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
So, another random thing I do

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
is the search for extraterrestrial intelligence,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
or SETI.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And you may be familiar with the movie "Contact,"

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
which sort of popularized that.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
It turns out there are real people who go out

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
and search for extraterrestrials in a very scientific way.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
In fact, almost everybody in the movie

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
is based on a real character, a real person.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
So, the Jodie Foster character here

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
is actually this woman, Jill Tarter,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
and Jill has dedicated her life to this.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
You know, a lot of people risk their lives

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
in a brief act of heroism,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
which is kind of cool,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
but Jill has

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
what I call slow heroism.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
She is risking her professional life on something

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
that her own calculations show

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
may not work for a thousand years -- may not ever.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
So, I like to support people that are risking their lives.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
After the movie came out, of course, there was a lot of interest in SETI.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
My kids saw the movie,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
and afterwards they came to me and they said,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
"So, Dad, so -- so --

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
that character -- that's Jill, right?"

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
I said, "Oh, yeah, yeah -- absolutely."

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
"And that other person, that's someone -- " I said, "Yes."

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
They said, "Well, you know that creepy rich guy in the movie?

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Is that you?"

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
I said, "Well, you know, it's just a movie! Come on."

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:48.958
(Laughter)

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
So, the SETI Institute,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
with a little bit of help from me, and a lot of help from Paul Allen

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
and a variety of other people,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
is building a dedicated radio telescope

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
in Hat Creek, California,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
so they can do this SETI work.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
Now, I travel a lot, and I change cell phones a lot,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
and the one person who always gets updated

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
on all my cell phones and pagers and everything else

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
is Jill, because I really don't want to miss

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
"the call."

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
(Laughter)

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
I mean, can you imagine? E.T.'s phoning home,

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
and I'm not, like, there? You know, horrible!

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
So, I do a lot of work on dinosaurs.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
I'm known to TEDsters as the guy that has sex with dinosaurs.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And I resemble that remark.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
I'm going to talk about a different aspect of dinosaurs,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
which is the finding of them.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
Now, to find dinosaurs, you hike around in horrible conditions

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
looking for a dinosaur.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
It sounds really dumb, but that's what it is.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
It's horrible conditions, because

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
wherever you have nice weather,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
plants grow,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and you don't get any erosion, and you don't see any dinosaurs.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So, you always find dinosaurs

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
in deserts or badlands,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
areas that have very little plant growth

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and have flash floods in the spring.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
You know, skiers pray for snow?

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
Paleontologists pray for erosion.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
So, you hike around

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and -- this is after you dig them up, they look like this.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
You hike around, you see something like this.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
Now, this is something I found, so look at it very closely here.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
You've got this bentonite clay,


00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
which is -- sort of swells up and expands.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
And there's some stuff poking out. So, you look at that,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and you look up close, and you say,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
"Well, gee, that's kind of interesting. What are all of these pieces?"

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
Well, if you look closely, you can recognize, actually,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
from the shape, that these are skull fragments.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
And then when you look at this,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
you say, "That's a tooth.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
It's a big tooth."

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
It's about the size of a banana.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
It has a big serration on the edge.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
This is what Tyrannosaurus rex looks like in the ground.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
And this is what it's like to find a Tyrannosaurus rex,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
which I was lucky enough to do a few years ago.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Now, this is what Tyrannosaurus rex looks like in my living room.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
Not the same one, actually. This is a cast, which I had bought,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
and then, after buying the cast, I found my own,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
and I don't have room for two.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
You know.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
So, the thing that's wonderful for me about finding dinosaurs

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
is that it is both an intellectual thing,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
because you're trying to reconstruct the environment

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
of millions of years ago.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
It's something that can inform all sorts of science

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
in unexpected ways.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
The study of dinosaurs led to the realization

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
that there's a problem with asteroid impact,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
for example.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
The study of dinosaurs may, literally,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
one day save the planet.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:38.958
Study of the ancient climate is very important.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
In fact, the Mesozoic, when dinosaurs lived,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
had much higher CO2 than today,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
was much warmer than today, and is one of the interesting proof points

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
for the effects of CO2 on climate.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
But, besides being intellectually

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
and scientifically interesting, it's also very different

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
than the other things I do, because you get to hike around in the badlands.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
This is actually what most dinosaur research looks like.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:06.958
This is one of my papers: "A pygostyle from a non-avian theropod."

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
It's not as gripping as dinosaur sex,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
so we're not going to go into it further.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
Now, I'm also really big on photography.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
I travel all over the world taking pictures --

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
some of them good, most of them not.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
These days, bits are cheap. Unfortunately, that means

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
you've got to spend more time sorting through them.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
Here's a picture I took in the Falkland Islands

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
of king penguins on a beach.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
Here's a picture I took in Alaska, a few years ago, of Orcas.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
I'd gone up to photograph Orcas,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
and we had looked for a week,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
and we hadn't seen a damn Orca.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And the last day, the sun comes out,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
the Orcas come, they're right by the boat. It's fantastic.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
And I get lots of pictures like this.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
Then, a little bit later,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
I start getting some pictures like this.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
Now, to a human audience, I need to explain that

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
if Penthouse magazine had a marine mammal edition,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
this would be the centerfold.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
It's true.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
So, there's more and more activity near the boat,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
and all of a sudden somebody shouts,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
"What's that in the water?"

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
I said, "Well, I think that's what you call a free willy."

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:21.958
(Laughter)

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
There's a variety of things you can learn from watching whales have sex.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
(Laughter)

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
The first thing you learn

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
is the overwhelming importance of hands.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
They don't have them.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
(Laughter)

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
I think Paul Simon is in the audience,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
and he has --

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
he may not realize it, but he wrote a song all about whale sex,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:46.958
"Slip-Slidin' Away."

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
That's kind of what it's like.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
The other interesting thing that I learned about whale sex:

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
they curl their toes too.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
(Laughter)

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
So --

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
where do you go putting all of these disparate pieces together?

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
You know, there's a tremendous amount of wisdom

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
in finding a great thing, passion in life,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
and focusing all your energy on it,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
and I've never been able to do that.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
I just -- you know, because, yes,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
I'll focus passion on something,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
but then there will be something else, and then there's something else again.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
And for a long time I fought this, and I thought,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
"Well, gee, I really ought to buckle down."

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
And you know, when I was at Microsoft,

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
that was so engrossing,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
and the whole industry was expanding so much,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:37.958
that it did tend to crowd out most of the other things in my life.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
But ultimately,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
I decided

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
that what I really ought to do is not fight being who I am,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
but embrace it.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
And say, "Yeah, you know, I --

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
this whole talk has been a mile wide and an inch deep,

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
but that's really what works for me."

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
And regardless of whether it's nuclear reactors

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
or metamaterials or whale sex,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.958
the common -- or lowest common denominator -- is me.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
That's it, thank you.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
(Applause)

title: The worldwide web of belief and ritual
transcript: You know, culture was born of the imagination, and the imagination — the imagination as we know it — came into being when our species descended from our progenitor, Homo erectus, and, infused with consciousness, began a journey that would carry it to every corner of the habitable world. For a time, we shared the stage with our distant cousins, Neanderthal, who clearly had some spark of awareness, but — whether it was the increase in the size of the brain, or the development of language, or some other evolutionary catalyst — we quickly left Neanderthal gasping for survival. By the time the last Neanderthal disappeared in Europe, 27,000 years ago, our direct ancestors had already, and for 5,000 years, been crawling into the belly of the earth, where in the light of the flickers of tallow candles, they had brought into being the great art of the Upper Paleolithic.And I spent two months in the caves of southwest France with the poet Clayton Eshleman, who wrote a beautiful book called "Juniper Fuse." And you could look at this art and you could, of course, see the complex social organization of the people who brought it into being. But more importantly, it spoke of a deeper yearning, something far more sophisticated than hunting magic. And the way Clayton put it was this way. He said, "You know, clearly at some point, we were all of an animal nature, and at some point, we weren't." And he viewed proto-shamanism as a kind of original attempt, through ritual, to rekindle a connection that had been irrevocably lost. So, he saw this art not as hunting magic, but as postcards of nostalgia. And viewed in that light, it takes on a whole other resonance.And the most amazing thing about the Upper Paleolithic art is that as an aesthetic expression, it lasted for almost 20,000 years. If these were postcards of nostalgia, ours was a very long farewell indeed. And it was also the beginning of our discontent, because if you wanted to distill all of our experience since the Paleolithic, it would come down to two words: how and why. And these are the slivers of insight upon which cultures have been forged. Now, all people share the same raw, adaptive imperatives. We all have children. We all have to deal with the mystery of death, the world that waits beyond death, the elders who fall away into their elderly years. All of this is part of our common experience, and this shouldn't surprise us, because, after all, biologists have finally proven it to be true, something that philosophers have always dreamt to be true. And that is the fact that we are all brothers and sisters. We are all cut from the same genetic cloth. All of humanity, probably, is descended from a thousand people who left Africa roughly 70,000 years ago.But the corollary of that is that, if we all are brothers and sisters and share the same genetic material, all human populations share the same raw human genius, the same intellectual acuity. And so whether that genius is placed into — technological wizardry has been the great achievement of the West — or by contrast, into unraveling the complex threads of memory inherent in a myth, is simply a matter of choice and cultural orientation. There is no progression of affairs in human experience. There is no trajectory of progress. There's no pyramid that conveniently places Victorian England at the apex and descends down the flanks to the so-called primitives of the world. All peoples are simply cultural options, different visions of life itself. But what do I mean by different visions of life making for completely different possibilities for existence?Well, let's slip for a moment into the greatest culture sphere ever brought into being by the imagination, that of Polynesia. 10,000 square kilometers, tens of thousands of islands flung like jewels upon the southern sea. I recently sailed on the Hokulea, named after the sacred star of Hawaii, throughout the South Pacific to make a film about the navigators. These are men and women who, even today, can name 250 stars in the night sky. These are men and women who can sense the presence of distant atolls of islands beyond the visible horizon, simply by watching the reverberation of waves across the hull of their vessel, knowing full well that every island group in the Pacific has its unique refractive pattern that can be read with the same perspicacity with which a forensic scientist would read a fingerprint. These are sailors who in the darkness, in the hull of the vessel, can distinguish as many as 32 different sea swells moving through the canoe at any one point in time, distinguishing local wave disturbances from the great currents that pulsate across the ocean, that can be followed with the same ease that a terrestrial explorer would follow a river to the sea. Indeed, if you took all of the genius that allowed us to put a man on the moon and applied it to an understanding of the ocean, what you would get is Polynesia.And if we slip from the realm of the sea into the realm of the spirit of the imagination, you enter the realm of Tibetan Buddhism. And I recently made a film called "The Buddhist Science of the Mind." Why did we use that word, science? What is science but the empirical pursuit of the truth? What is Buddhism but 2,500 years of empirical observation as to the nature of mind? I travelled for a month in Nepal with our good friend, Matthieu Ricard, and you'll remember Matthieu famously said to all of us here once at TED, "Western science is a major response to minor needs." We spend all of our lifetime trying to live to be 100 without losing our teeth. The Buddhist spends all their lifetime trying to understand the nature of existence.Our billboards celebrate naked children in underwear. Their billboards are manuals, prayers to the well-being of all sentient creatures. And with the blessing of Trulshik Rinpoche, we began a pilgrimage to a curious destination, accompanied by a great doctor. And the destination was a single room in a nunnery, where a woman had gone into lifelong retreat 55 years before. And en route, we took darshan from Rinpoche, and he sat with us and told us about the Four Noble Truths, the essence of the Buddhist path. All life is suffering. That doesn't mean all life is negative. It means things happen. The cause of suffering is ignorance. By that, the Buddha did not mean stupidity; he meant clinging to the illusion that life is static and predictable. The third noble truth said that ignorance can be overcome. And the fourth and most important, of course, was the delineation of a contemplative practice that not only had the possibility of a transformation of the human heart, but had 2,500 years of empirical evidence that such a transformation was a certainty.And so, when this door opened onto the face of a woman who had not been out of that room in 55 years, you did not see a mad woman. You saw a woman who was more clear than a pool of water in a mountain stream. And of course, this is what the Tibetan monks told us. They said, at one point, you know, we don't really believe you went to the moon, but you did. You may not believe that we achieve enlightenment in one lifetime, but we do. And if we move from the realm of the spirit to the realm of the physical, to the sacred geography of Peru — I've always been interested in the relationships of indigenous people that literally believe that the Earth is alive, responsive to all of their aspirations, all of their needs. And, of course, the human population has its own reciprocal obligations.I spent 30 years living amongst the people of Chinchero and I always heard about an event that I always wanted to participate in. Once each year, the fastest young boy in each hamlet is given the honor of becoming a woman. And for one day, he wears the clothing of his sister and he becomes a transvestite, a waylaka. And for that day, he leads all able-bodied men on a run, but it's not your ordinary run. You start off at 11,500 feet. You run down to the base of the sacred mountain, Antakillqa. You run up to 15,000 feet, descend 3,000 feet. Climb again over the course of 24 hours. And of course, the waylakama spin, the trajectory of the route, is marked by holy mounds of Earth, where coke is given to the Earth, libations of alcohol to the wind, the vortex of the feminine is brought to the mountaintop. And the metaphor is clear: you go into the mountain as an individual, but through exhaustion, through sacrifice, you emerge as a community that has once again reaffirmed its sense of place in the planet. And at 48, I was the only outsider ever to go through this, only one to finish it. I only managed to do it by chewing more coca leaves in one day than anyone in the 4,000-year history of the plant.But these localized rituals become pan-Andean, and these fantastic festivals, like that of the Qoyllur Rit'i, which occurs when the Pleiades reappear in the winter sky. It's kind of like an Andean Woodstock: 60,000 Indians on pilgrimage to the end of a dirt road that leads to the sacred valley, called the Sinakara, which is dominated by three tongues of the great glacier. The metaphor is so clear. You bring the crosses from your community, in this wonderful fusion of Christian and pre-Columbian ideas. You place the cross into the ice, in the shadow of Ausangate, the most sacred of all Apus, or sacred mountains of the Inca. And then you do the ritual dances that empower the crosses.Now, these ideas and these events allow us even to deconstruct iconic places that many of you have been to, like Machu Picchu. Machu Picchu was never a lost city. On the contrary, it was completely linked in to the 14,000 kilometers of royal roads the Inca made in less than a century. But more importantly, it was linked in to the Andean notions of sacred geography. The intiwatana, the hitching post to the sun, is actually an obelisk that constantly reflects the light that falls on the sacred Apu of Machu Picchu, which is Sugarloaf Mountain, called Huayna Picchu. If you come to the south of the intiwatana, you find an altar. Climb Huayna Picchu, find another altar. Take a direct north-south bearing, you find to your astonishment that it bisects the intiwatana stone, goes to the skyline, hits the heart of Salcantay, the second of the most important mountains of the Incan empire. And then beyond Salcantay, of course, when the southern cross reaches the southernmost point in the sky, directly in that same alignment, the Milky Way overhead. But what is enveloping Machu Picchu from below? The sacred river, the Urubamba, or the Vilcanota, which is itself the Earthly equivalent of the Milky Way, but it's also the trajectory that Viracocha walked at the dawn of time when he brought the universe into being. And where does the river rise? Right on the slopes of the Koariti.So, 500 years after Columbus, these ancient rhythms of landscape are played out in ritual. Now, when I was here at the first TED, I showed this photograph: two men of the Elder Brothers, the descendants, survivors of El Dorado. These, of course, are the descendants of the ancient Tairona civilization. If those of you who are here remember that I mentioned that they remain ruled by a ritual priesthood, but the training for the priesthood is extraordinary. Taken from their families, sequestered in a shadowy world of darkness for 18 years — two nine-year periods deliberately chosen to evoke the nine months they spend in the natural mother's womb. All that time, the world only exists as an abstraction, as they are taught the values of their society. Values that maintain the proposition that their prayers, and their prayers alone, maintain the cosmic balance. Now, the measure of a society is not only what it does, but the quality of its aspirations.And I always wanted to go back into these mountains, to see if this could possibly be true, as indeed had been reported by the great anthropologist, Reichel-Dolmatoff. So, literally two weeks ago, I returned from having spent six weeks with the Elder Brothers on what was clearly the most extraordinary trip of my life. These really are a people who live and breathe the realm of the sacred, a baroque religiosity that is simply awesome. They consume more coca leaves than any human population, half a pound per man, per day. The gourd you see here is — everything in their lives is symbolic. Their central metaphor is a loom. They say, "Upon this loom, I weave my life." They refer to the movements as they exploit the ecological niches of the gradient as "threads." When they pray for the dead, they make these gestures with their hands, spinning their thoughts into the heavens.You can see the calcium buildup on the head of the poporo gourd. The gourd is a feminine aspect; the stick is a male. You put the stick in the powder to take the sacred ashes — well, they're not ashes, they're burnt limestone — to empower the coca leaf, to change the pH of the mouth to facilitate the absorption of cocaine hydrochloride. But if you break a gourd, you cannot simply throw it away, because every stroke of that stick that has built up that calcium, the measure of a man's life, has a thought behind it. Fields are planted in such an extraordinary way, that the one side of the field is planted like that by the women. The other side is planted like that by the men. Metaphorically, you turn it on the side, and you have a piece of cloth. And they are the descendants of the ancient Tairona civilization, the greatest goldsmiths of South America, who in the wake of the conquest, retreated into this isolated volcanic massif that soars to 20,000 feet above the Caribbean coastal plain.There are four societies: the Kogi, the Wiwa, the Kankwano and the Arhuacos. I traveled with the Arhuacos, and the wonderful thing about this story was that this man, Danilo Villafane — if we just jump back here for a second. When I first met Danilo, in the Colombian embassy in Washington, I couldn't help but say, "You know, you look a lot like an old friend of mine." Well, it turns out he was the son of my friend, Adalberto, from 1974, who had been killed by the FARC. And I said, "Danilo, you won't remember this, but when you were an infant, I carried you on my back, up and down the mountains." And because of that, Danilo invited us to go to the very heart of the world, a place where no journalist had ever been permitted. Not simply to the flanks of the mountains, but to the very iced peaks which are the destiny of the pilgrims.And this man sitting cross-legged is now a grown-up Eugenio, a man who I've known since 1974. And this is one of those initiates. No, it's not true that they're kept in the darkness for 18 years, but they are kept within the confines of the ceremonial men's circle for 18 years. This little boy will never step outside of the sacred fields that surround the men's hut for all that time, until he begins his journey of initiation. For that entire time, the world only exists as an abstraction, as he is taught the values of society, including this notion that their prayers alone maintain the cosmic balance. Before we could begin our journey, we had to be cleansed at the portal of the Earth. And it was extraordinary to be taken by a priest. And you see that the priest never wears shoes because holy feet — there must be nothing between the feet and the Earth for a mamo. And this is actually the place where the Great Mother sent the spindle into the world that elevated the mountains and created the homeland that they call the heart of the world.We traveled high into the paramo, and as we crested the hills, we realized that the men were interpreting every single bump on the landscape in terms of their own intense religiosity. And then of course, as we reached our final destination, a place called Mamancana, we were in for a surprise, because the FARC were waiting to kidnap us. And so we ended up being taken aside into these huts, hidden away until the darkness. And then, abandoning all our gear, we were forced to ride out in the middle of the night, in a quite dramatic scene. It's going to look like a John Ford Western. And we ran into a FARC patrol at dawn, so it was quite harrowing. It will be a very interesting film. But what was fascinating is that the minute there was a sense of dangers, the mamos went into a circle of divination.And of course, this is a photograph literally taken the night we were in hiding, as they divine their route to take us out of the mountains. We were able to, because we had trained people in filmmaking, continue with our work, and send our Wiwa and Arhuaco filmmakers to the final sacred lakes to get the last shots for the film, and we followed the rest of the Arhuaco back to the sea, taking the elements from the highlands to the sea. And here you see how their sacred landscape has been covered by brothels and hotels and casinos, and yet, still they pray. And it's an amazing thing to think that this close to Miami, two hours from Miami, there is an entire civilization of people praying every day for your well-being. They call themselves the Elder Brothers. They dismiss the rest of us who have ruined the world as the Younger Brothers. They cannot understand why it is that we do what we do to the Earth.Now, if we slip to another end of the world, I was up in the high Arctic to tell a story about global warming, inspired in part by the former Vice President's wonderful book. And what struck me so extraordinary was to be again with the Inuit — a people who don't fear the cold, but take advantage of it. A people who find a way, with their imagination, to carve life out of that very frozen. A people for whom blood on ice is not a sign of death, but an affirmation of life. And yet tragically, when you now go to those northern communities, you find to your astonishment that whereas the sea ice used to come in in September and stay till July, in a place like Kanak in northern Greenland, it literally comes in now in November and stays until March. So, their entire year has been cut in half.Now, I want to stress that none of these peoples that I've been quickly talking about here are disappearing worlds. These are not dying peoples. On the contrary, you know, if you have the heart to feel and the eyes to see, you discover that the world is not flat. The world remains a rich tapestry. It remains a rich topography of the spirit. These myriad voices of humanity are not failed attempts at being new, failed attempts at being modern. They're unique facets of the human imagination. They're unique answers to a fundamental question: what does it mean to be human and alive? And when asked that question, they respond with 6,000 different voices. And collectively, those voices become our human repertoire for dealing with the challenges that will confront us in the ensuing millennia.Our industrial society is scarcely 300 years old. That shallow history shouldn't suggest to anyone that we have all of the answers for all of the questions that will confront us in the ensuing millennia. The myriad voices of humanity are not failed attempts at being us. They are unique answers to that fundamental question: what does it mean to be human and alive? And there is indeed a fire burning over the Earth, taking with it not only plants and animals, but the legacy of humanity's brilliance.Right now, as we sit here in this room, of those 6,000 languages spoken the day that you were born, fully half aren't being taught to children. So, you're living through a time when virtually half of humanity's intellectual, social and spiritual legacy is being allowed to slip away. This does not have to happen. These peoples are not failed attempts at being modern — quaint and colorful and destined to fade away as if by natural law.In every case, these are dynamic, living peoples being driven out of existence by identifiable forces. That's actually an optimistic observation, because it suggests that if human beings are the agents of cultural destruction, we can also be, and must be, the facilitators of cultural survival.Thank you very much.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
You know, culture was born of the imagination,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:18.958
and the imagination -- the imagination as we know it --

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
came into being when our species descended

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
from our progenitor, Homo erectus,

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
and, infused with consciousness, began a journey that would carry it

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
to every corner of the habitable world.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:33.958
For a time, we shared the stage with our distant cousins, Neanderthal,

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
who clearly had some spark of awareness,

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:38.958
but -- whether it was the increase in the size of the brain,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
or the development of language,

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
or some other evolutionary catalyst --

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:46.958
we quickly left Neanderthal gasping for survival.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:49.958
By the time the last Neanderthal disappeared in Europe,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:51.958
27,000 years ago,

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
our direct ancestors had already,

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
and for 5,000 years,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
been crawling into the belly of the earth,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:00.958
where in the light of the flickers of tallow candles,

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
they had brought into being

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
the great art of the Upper Paleolithic.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
And I spent two months in the caves of southwest France

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
with the poet Clayton Eshleman, who wrote a beautiful book called "Juniper Fuse."

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:12.958
And you could look at this art and you could, of course,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
see the complex social organization

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
of the people who brought it into being.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
But more importantly, it spoke of a deeper yearning,

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
something far more sophisticated than hunting magic.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
And the way Clayton put it was this way.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:28.958
He said, "You know, clearly at some point,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
we were all of an animal nature, and at some point, we weren't."

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
And he viewed proto-shamanism as a kind of original attempt,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
through ritual, to rekindle a connection

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
that had been irrevocably lost.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
So, he saw this art not as

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:44.958
hunting magic, but as postcards of nostalgia.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
And viewed in that light,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
it takes on a whole other resonance.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
And the most amazing thing about the Upper Paleolithic art

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
is that as an aesthetic expression,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
it lasted for almost 20,000 years.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
If these were postcards of nostalgia,

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:02.958
ours was a very long farewell indeed.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
And it was also the beginning of our discontent,

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
because if you wanted to distill all of our experience

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
since the Paleolithic, it would come down to two words:

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
how and why.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
And these are the slivers of insight upon which cultures have been forged.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
Now, all people share the same

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
raw, adaptive imperatives.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
We all have children.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
We all have to deal with the mystery of death,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
the world that waits beyond death,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
the elders who fall away into their elderly years.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
All of this is part of our common experience,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
and this shouldn't surprise us, because, after all,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
biologists have finally proven it to be true,

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:36.958
something that philosophers have always dreamt to be true.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
And that is the fact that we are all brothers and sisters.

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
We are all cut from the same genetic cloth.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
All of humanity, probably, is descended from a thousand people

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
who left Africa roughly 70,000 years ago.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
But the corollary of that is that,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
if we all are brothers and sisters

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
and share the same genetic material,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
all human populations share the same raw human genius,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
the same intellectual acuity.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
And so whether that genius is placed

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
into -- technological wizardry

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
has been the great achievement of the West --

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
or by contrast, into unraveling the complex threads

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
of memory inherent in a myth,

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
is simply a matter of choice and cultural orientation.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
There is no progression of affairs

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
in human experience.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
There is no trajectory of progress. There's no pyramid

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
that conveniently places Victorian England at the apex

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
and descends down the flanks

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
to the so-called primitives of the world.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
All peoples are simply cultural options,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
different visions of life itself.

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
But what do I mean by different visions of life

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
making for completely different

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
possibilities for existence?

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
Well, let's slip for a moment into the greatest culture sphere

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
ever brought into being by the imagination,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
that of Polynesia.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
10,000 square kilometers,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
tens of thousands of islands flung like jewels upon the southern sea.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
I recently sailed on the Hokulea,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
named after the sacred star of Hawaii,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
throughout the South Pacific to make a film

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
about the navigators.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
These are men and women who, even today, can name

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
250 stars in the night sky.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
These are men and women who can sense the presence of distant atolls

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
of islands beyond the visible horizon,

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
simply by watching the reverberation of waves

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
across the hull of their vessel, knowing full well

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
that every island group in the Pacific

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
has its unique refractive pattern

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
that can be read with the same perspicacity

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
with which a forensic scientist would read a fingerprint.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
These are sailors who in the darkness, in the hull of the vessel,

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
can distinguish as many as 32 different sea swells

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
moving through the canoe at any one point in time,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
distinguishing local wave disturbances

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
from the great currents that pulsate across the ocean,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
that can be followed with the same ease

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
that a terrestrial explorer would follow a river to the sea.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
Indeed, if you took all of the genius

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
that allowed us to put a man on the moon

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
and applied it to an understanding of the ocean,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
what you would get is Polynesia.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
And if we slip from the realm of the sea

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
into the realm of the spirit of the imagination,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
you enter the realm of Tibetan Buddhism.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
And I recently made a film called "The Buddhist Science of the Mind."

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
Why did we use that word, science?

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
What is science but the empirical pursuit of the truth?

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
What is Buddhism but 2,500 years

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
of empirical observation

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
as to the nature of mind?

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
I travelled for a month in Nepal with our good friend, Matthieu Ricard,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
and you'll remember Matthieu famously said to all of us

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
here once at TED,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
"Western science is a major response to minor needs."

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
We spend all of our lifetime trying to live to be 100

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
without losing our teeth.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
The Buddhist spends all their lifetime trying to understand the nature of existence.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
Our billboards celebrate naked children in underwear.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
Their billboards are manuals,

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
prayers to the well-being of all sentient creatures.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And with the blessing of Trulshik Rinpoche, we began a pilgrimage

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
to a curious destination,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
accompanied by a great doctor.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
And the destination was a single room in a nunnery,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
where a woman had gone into lifelong retreat

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
55 years before.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
And en route, we took darshan from Rinpoche,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
and he sat with us and told us about the Four Noble Truths,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
the essence of the Buddhist path.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
All life is suffering. That doesn't mean all life is negative.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
It means things happen.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
The cause of suffering is ignorance.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
By that, the Buddha did not mean stupidity;

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
he meant clinging to the illusion

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
that life is static and predictable.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
The third noble truth said that ignorance can be overcome.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
And the fourth and most important, of course,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
was the delineation of a contemplative practice

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
that not only had the possibility

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
of a transformation of the human heart,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
but had 2,500 years of empirical evidence

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
that such a transformation was a certainty.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
And so, when this door opened onto the face of a woman

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
who had not been out of that room in 55 years,

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
you did not see a mad woman.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
You saw a woman who was more clear

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
than a pool of water in a mountain stream.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
And of course, this is what the Tibetan monks told us.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
They said, at one point, you know, we don't really believe

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
you went to the moon, but you did.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
You may not believe that we achieve enlightenment

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
in one lifetime, but we do.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
And if we move from the realm of the spirit

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
to the realm of the physical,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
to the sacred geography of Peru --

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
I've always been interested in the relationships of indigenous people

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
that literally believe that the Earth is alive,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
responsive to all of their aspirations,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
all of their needs.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
And, of course, the human population

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
has its own reciprocal obligations.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
I spent 30 years living amongst

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
the people of Chinchero

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
and I always heard about an event that I always wanted to participate in.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
Once each year, the fastest young boy

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
in each hamlet is given the honor of becoming a woman.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
And for one day, he wears the clothing of his sister

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
and he becomes a transvestite,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
a waylaka. And for that day,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
he leads all able-bodied men on a run,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
but it's not your ordinary run.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
You start off at 11,500 feet.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
You run down to the base of the sacred mountain, Antakillqa.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
You run up to 15,000 feet,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
descend 3,000 feet.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
Climb again over the course of 24 hours.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
And of course, the waylakama spin,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
the trajectory of the route,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
is marked by holy mounds of Earth,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
where coke is given to the Earth, libations of alcohol to the wind,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
the vortex of the feminine is brought to the mountaintop.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
And the metaphor is clear: you go into the mountain as an individual,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
but through exhaustion, through sacrifice,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
you emerge as a community that has once again

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
reaffirmed its sense of place in the planet.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
And at 48, I was the only outsider ever to go through this,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
only one to finish it.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
I only managed to do it by chewing more coca leaves in one day

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
than anyone in the 4,000-year history of the plant.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
But these localized rituals become pan-Andean,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
and these fantastic festivals,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
like that of the Qoyllur Rit'i, which occurs

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
when the Pleiades reappear in the winter sky.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
It's kind of like an Andean Woodstock:

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
60,000 Indians on pilgrimage

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
to the end of a dirt road

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
that leads to the sacred valley, called the Sinakara,

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
which is dominated by three tongues

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
of the great glacier.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
The metaphor is so clear. You bring the crosses from your community,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
in this wonderful fusion of Christian

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
and pre-Columbian ideas.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
You place the cross into the ice,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
in the shadow of Ausangate, the most sacred of all Apus,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
or sacred mountains of the Inca.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
And then you do the ritual dances that empower the crosses.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
Now, these ideas and these events

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
allow us even to deconstruct iconic places

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
that many of you have been to, like Machu Picchu.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
Machu Picchu was never a lost city.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
On the contrary, it was completely linked in

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
to the 14,000 kilometers of royal roads

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
the Inca made in less than a century.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
But more importantly, it was linked in

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
to the Andean notions of sacred geography.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
The intiwatana, the hitching post to the sun,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
is actually an obelisk that constantly reflects the light

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
that falls on the sacred Apu of Machu Picchu,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
which is Sugarloaf Mountain, called Huayna Picchu.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
If you come to the south of the intiwatana, you find an altar.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
Climb Huayna Picchu, find another altar.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
Take a direct north-south bearing,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
you find to your astonishment

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
that it bisects the intiwatana stone,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
goes to the skyline,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
hits the heart of Salcantay, the second of the most important mountains

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
of the Incan empire.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
And then beyond Salcantay, of course,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
when the southern cross reaches the southernmost point in the sky,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
directly in that same alignment, the Milky Way overhead.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
But what is enveloping Machu Picchu from below?

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
The sacred river, the Urubamba, or the Vilcanota,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
which is itself the Earthly equivalent of the Milky Way,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
but it's also the trajectory that Viracocha walked

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
at the dawn of time when he brought the universe into being.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
And where does the river rise?

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Right on the slopes of the Koariti.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
So, 500 years after Columbus,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
these ancient rhythms of landscape

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
are played out in ritual.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
Now, when I was here at the first TED,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
I showed this photograph: two men of the Elder Brothers,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
the descendants, survivors of El Dorado.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
These, of course, are the descendants

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
of the ancient Tairona civilization.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
If those of you who are here remember that I mentioned

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
that they remain ruled by a ritual priesthood,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
but the training for the priesthood is extraordinary.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
Taken from their families, sequestered in a shadowy world of darkness

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
for 18 years -- two nine-year periods deliberately chosen

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
to evoke the nine months they spend in the natural mother's womb.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:57.958
All that time, the world only exists as an abstraction,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
as they are taught the values of their society.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Values that maintain the proposition that their prayers,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
and their prayers alone, maintain the cosmic balance.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
Now, the measure of a society is not only what it does,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
but the quality of its aspirations.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
And I always wanted to go back into these mountains,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
to see if this could possibly be true,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
as indeed had been reported by the great anthropologist,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
Reichel-Dolmatoff.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
So, literally two weeks ago,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
I returned from having spent six weeks with the Elder Brothers

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
on what was clearly the most

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
extraordinary trip of my life.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
These really are a people who live and breathe

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
the realm of the sacred,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
a baroque religiosity that is simply awesome.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
They consume more coca leaves than any human population,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
half a pound per man, per day.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
The gourd you see here is --

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
everything in their lives is symbolic.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
Their central metaphor is a loom.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
They say, "Upon this loom, I weave my life."

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
They refer to the movements as they exploit the ecological niches of the gradient

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
as "threads."

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
When they pray for the dead, they make these gestures with their hands,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
spinning their thoughts into the heavens.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
You can see the calcium buildup on the head of the poporo gourd.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
The gourd is a feminine aspect; the stick is a male.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
You put the stick in the powder

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
to take the sacred ashes -- well, they're not ashes,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:14.958
they're burnt limestone --

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
to empower the coca leaf, to change

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
the pH of the mouth to facilitate the absorption

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
of cocaine hydrochloride.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
But if you break a gourd, you cannot simply throw it away,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
because every stroke of that stick

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
that has built up that calcium,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
the measure of a man's life,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
has a thought behind it.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
Fields are planted in such an extraordinary way,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
that the one side of the field

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
is planted like that by the women.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
The other side is planted like that by the men. Metaphorically,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
you turn it on the side, and you have a piece of cloth.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
And they are the descendants of the ancient Tairona civilization,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:48.958
the greatest goldsmiths of South America,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
who in the wake of the conquest,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
retreated into this isolated volcanic massif

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
that soars to 20,000 feet

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
above the Caribbean coastal plain.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
There are four societies:

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
the Kogi, the Wiwa, the Kankwano and the Arhuacos.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
I traveled with the Arhuacos,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
and the wonderful thing about this story

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
was that this man, Danilo Villafane --

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
if we just jump back here for a second.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
When I first met Danilo, in the Colombian embassy in Washington,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
I couldn't help but say, "You know,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
you look a lot like an old friend of mine."

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
Well, it turns out he was the son of my friend, Adalberto,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
from 1974, who had been killed by the FARC.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
And I said, "Danilo, you won't remember this,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
but when you were an infant, I carried you on my back,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
up and down the mountains."

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
And because of that, Danilo invited us

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
to go to the very heart of the world,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
a place where no journalist had ever been permitted.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
Not simply to the flanks of the mountains,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
but to the very iced peaks which are the destiny of the pilgrims.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
And this man sitting cross-legged

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
is now a grown-up Eugenio,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
a man who I've known since 1974.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
And this is one of those initiates.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
No, it's not true that they're kept in the darkness for 18 years,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
but they are kept within the confines

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
of the ceremonial men's circle

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
for 18 years.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
This little boy will never step outside

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
of the sacred fields

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
that surround the men's hut for all that time,

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
until he begins his journey of initiation.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
For that entire time, the world only exists as an abstraction,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
as he is taught the values of society,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
including this notion that their prayers alone

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
maintain the cosmic balance.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
Before we could begin our journey,

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
we had to be cleansed at the portal of the Earth.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And it was extraordinary to be taken by a priest.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
And you see that the priest never wears shoes because holy feet --

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
there must be nothing between the feet

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
and the Earth for a mamo.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
And this is actually the place where the Great Mother

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
sent the spindle into the world

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
that elevated the mountains and created the homeland

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
that they call the heart of the world.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
We traveled high into the paramo,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and as we crested the hills,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
we realized that the men were interpreting

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
every single bump on the landscape

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
in terms of their own intense religiosity.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.958
And then of course, as we reached our final destination,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
a place called Mamancana,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
we were in for a surprise,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
because the FARC were waiting to kidnap us.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
And so we ended up being taken aside into these huts,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
hidden away until the darkness.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
And then, abandoning all our gear,

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
we were forced to ride out in the middle of the night,

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
in a quite dramatic scene.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
It's going to look like a John Ford Western.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
And we ran into a FARC patrol at dawn, so it was quite harrowing.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
It will be a very interesting film. But what was fascinating

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
is that the minute there was a sense of dangers,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
the mamos went into a circle of divination.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
And of course, this is a photograph

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
literally taken the night we were in hiding,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
as they divine their route

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
to take us out of the mountains.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
We were able to, because we had trained

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
people in filmmaking,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
continue with our work,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
and send our Wiwa and Arhuaco filmmakers

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
to the final sacred lakes

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
to get the last shots for the film,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
and we followed the rest of the Arhuaco back to the sea,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
taking the elements from the highlands to the sea.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
And here you see how their sacred landscape

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
has been covered by brothels and hotels and casinos,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
and yet, still they pray.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
And it's an amazing thing to think

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
that this close to Miami,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
two hours from Miami, there is an entire civilization of people

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
praying every day for your well-being.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
They call themselves the Elder Brothers.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
They dismiss the rest of us who have ruined the world

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
as the Younger Brothers. They cannot understand

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
why it is that we do what we do to the Earth.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
Now, if we slip to another end of the world,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
I was up in the high Arctic

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
to tell a story about global warming,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
inspired in part by

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
the former Vice President's wonderful book.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
And what struck me so extraordinary

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
was to be again with the Inuit --

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
a people who don't fear the cold, but take advantage of it.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
A people who

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
find a way, with their imagination,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
to carve life out of that very frozen.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
A people for whom blood on ice

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
is not a sign of death, but an affirmation of life.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
And yet tragically, when you now go to those northern communities,

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
you find to your astonishment

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
that whereas the sea ice used to come in in September

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
and stay till July,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
in a place like Kanak in northern Greenland,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
it literally comes in now in November

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
and stays until March.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
So, their entire year has been cut in half.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
Now, I want to stress that none of these peoples

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
that I've been quickly talking about here

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
are disappearing worlds.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:17.958
These are not dying peoples.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:19.958
On the contrary, you know,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
if you have the heart to feel and the eyes to see,

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
you discover that the world is not flat.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
The world remains a rich tapestry.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
It remains a rich topography of the spirit.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
These myriad voices of humanity

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
are not failed attempts at being new,

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
failed attempts at being modern.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
They're unique facets of the human imagination.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
They're unique answers to a fundamental question:

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:43.958
what does it mean to be human and alive?

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
And when asked that question, they respond

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
with 6,000 different voices.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
And collectively, those voices become our human repertoire

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
for dealing with the challenges that will confront us

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
in the ensuing millennia.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:56.958
Our industrial society is scarcely

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
300 years old.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:00.958
That shallow history shouldn't suggest to anyone

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:02.958
that we have all of the answers

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
for all of the questions that will confront us

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
in the ensuing millennia.

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:09.958
The myriad voices of humanity are not failed attempts at being us.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
They are unique answers to that fundamental question:

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.958
what does it mean to be human and alive?

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
And there is indeed a fire burning over the Earth,

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:20.958
taking with it not only plants and animals,

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:22.958
but the legacy of humanity's brilliance.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
Right now, as we sit here in this room,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:27.958
of those 6,000 languages spoken the day that you were born,

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:30.958
fully half aren't being taught to children.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:31.958
So, you're living through a time

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:34.958
when virtually half of humanity's intellectual,

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:36.958
social and spiritual legacy

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:38.958
is being allowed to slip away.

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:40.958
This does not have to happen.

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:43.958
These peoples are not failed attempts at being modern --

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
quaint and colorful and destined to fade away

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
as if by natural law.

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:49.958
In every case, these are dynamic, living peoples

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:52.958
being driven out of existence by identifiable forces.

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:55.958
That's actually an optimistic observation,

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:57.958
because it suggests that if human beings

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
are the agents of cultural destruction,

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
we can also be, and must be,

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
the facilitators of cultural survival.

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:05.958
Thank you very much.

title: The ancestor of language
transcript: Well, I'm involved in other things, besides physics. In fact, mostly now in other things.One thing is distant relationships among human languages. And the professional, historical linguists in the U.S. and in Western Europe mostly try to stay away from any long-distance relationships, big groupings, groupings that go back a long time, longer than the familiar families. They don't like that. They think it's crank. I don't think it's crank. And there are some brilliant linguists, mostly Russians, who are working on that, at Santa Fe Institute and in Moscow, and I would love to see where that leads.Does it really lead to a single ancestor some 20, 25,000 years ago? And what if we go back beyond that single ancestor, when there was presumably a competition among many languages? How far back does that go? How far back does modern language go? How many tens of thousands of years does it go back?Chris Anderson: Do you have a hunch or a hope for what the answer to that is?Murray Gell-Mann: Well, I would guess that modern language must be older than the cave paintings and cave engravings and cave sculptures and dance steps in the soft clay in the caves in Western Europe, in the Aurignacian Period some 35,000 years ago, or earlier. I can't believe they did all those things and didn't also have a modern language. So, I would guess that the actual origin goes back at least that far and maybe further.But that doesn't mean that all, or many, or most of today's attested languages couldn't descend perhaps from one that's much younger than that, like say 20,000 years, or something of that kind. It's what we call a bottleneck.CA: Well, Philip Anderson may have been right. You may just know more about everything than anyone. So, it's been an honor. Thank you Murray Gell-Mann. (Applause)
